Bipolar and Related Disorders.title: Bipolar and Related Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of mood disturbances that include episodes of mania, hypomania, and depression.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Mood episodes represent a change from the individual's usual behavior and functioning.

differentialDiagnosis: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Bipolar I Disorder.title: Bipolar I Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria have been met for at least one manic episode.
subcriteria: 1. A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

2. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior: inflated self-esteem or grandiosity; decreased need for sleep; more talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking; flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing; distractibility; increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation; excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The manic episode may be preceded or followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The manic episode is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Bipolar I Disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary) for manic episode.

Bipolar II Disorder.title: Bipolar II Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria have been met for at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode.
subcriteria: 1. Hypomanic Episode: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 4 consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.

2. Major Depressive Episode: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The occurrence of the hypomanic episode(s) and major depressive episode(s) is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Bipolar II Disorder.timeFrame: Hypomanic episode: at least 4 consecutive days; Major depressive episode: at least 2 weeks.
associatedFeatures: Heightened creativity or productivity during hypomanic episodes

Cyclothymic Disorder.title: Cyclothymic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been numerous periods with hypomanic symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode and numerous periods with depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the above 2-year period (1 year in children and adolescents), the hypomanic and depressive periods have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not been without the symptoms for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode have never been met.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms in Criterion A are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism).

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Cyclothymic Disorder.timeFrame: At least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents)
associatedFeatures: Impairment in social or occupational functioning
Increased risk for developing bipolar I or II disorder

Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and Related Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, with or without depressed mood, or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both (1) and (2):
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the mood disturbance.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a bipolar or related disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent bipolar or related disorder could include: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence suggesting the existence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced bipolar and related disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may include mania, hypomania, or depression.
Symptoms are temporally related to substance use or withdrawal.
differentialDiagnosis: Substance Intoxication or Withdrawal with Delirium
Mood Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Anot.title: Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally increased activity or energy that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, with mixed features, in response to the stress of having a general medical condition).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning, or necessitates hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may fluctuate with the course of the medical condition
comorbidity: Other mental disorders related to the underlying medical condition

Other Specified Bipolar and Related Diso.title: Other Specified Bipolar and Related Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms characteristic of a bipolar and related disorder that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning predominate.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The full criteria for any of the disorders in the bipolar and related disorders diagnostic class are not met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses to communicate the specific reason that the presentation does not meet the criteria for any specific bipolar and related disorder.

specifiers: Short-duration hypomanic episodes (2–3 days) and major depressive episodes
Hypomanic episodes with insufficient symptoms and major depressive episodes
Hypomanic episode without prior major depressive episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms characteristic of a bipolar and related disorder that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms do not meet the full criteria for any of the disorders in the bipolar and related disorders diagnostic class.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses not to specify the reason that the criteria are not met for a specific bipolar and related disorder, or there is insufficient information to make a more specific diagnosis.

Manic Episode.title: Manic Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation (i.e., purposeless non-goal-directed activity).
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or other treatment) or to another medical condition.

Manic Episode.timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Episode with Mixed Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least four consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) have persisted, represent a noticeable change from usual behavior, and have been present to a significant degree:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation.
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharacteristic of the individual when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance in mood and the change in functioning are observable by others.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. If there are psychotic features, the episode is, by definition, manic.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day.
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Psychomotor Agitation.title: Psychomotor Agitation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Excessive motor activity associated with a feeling of inner tension, observable by others.
subcriteria: 1. Pacing.
2. Fidgeting.
3. Inability to sit still.

associatedFeatures: May be present in mood disorders such as Major Depressive Episode or Manic Episode.
Often accompanied by subjective feelings of restlessness or anxiety.

Psychomotor Retardation.title: Psychomotor Retardation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A visible slowing of physical and emotional reactions, including speech and movement.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in mood disorders such as Major Depressive Disorder.
Can affect daily functioning and social interactions.

Grandiosity.title: Grandiosity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An inflated sense of self-importance, power, knowledge, identity, or abilities.
subcriteria: 1. The individual may believe they possess special talents, powers, or insights.
2. The individual may overestimate their achievements or capabilities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Grandiosity is most commonly observed as a symptom during manic or hypomanic episodes.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by decreased need for sleep, increased goal-directed activity, or distractibility.
Often associated with impulsivity and poor judgment.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A tendency for attention to be easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli, either as reported by the individual or observed by others.

Goal-Directed Activity.title: Goal-Directed Activity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Purposeful, focused activity aimed at achieving specific objectives.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: May be increased during manic or hypomanic episodes.

associatedFeatures: Often observed as increased productivity, social engagement, or involvement in projects during mood episodes.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of delusions or hallucinations at any time during a mood episode.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period during which the symptoms of a disorder are reduced (partial remission) or absent (full remission).

Depressed mood.title: Depressed Mood

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive feeling of sadness, emptiness, or hopelessness most of the day, nearly every day, as indicated by subjective report or observation by others.

Depressed mood.timeFrame: Most of the day, nearly every day

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A natural emotional response to loss, typically following the death of a loved one.
subcriteria: 1. Persistent feelings of sadness, emptiness, or yearning related to the loss.
2. Preoccupation with thoughts or memories of the deceased.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The emotional response is typically triggered or intensified by reminders of the deceased.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Self-esteem is generally preserved, and the individual retains the capacity for positive emotions and humor.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Symptoms decrease in intensity over time and are closely tied to the loss.

Major Depressive Episode (MDE).title: Major Depressive Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day.
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of recurrent thoughts that are critical or negative about oneself.
subcriteria: 1. Thoughts often involve feelings of failure or inadequacy.
2. Thoughts may include self-criticism, feelings of worthlessness, or self-blame.

Manic episode.title: Manic Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation.
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or other treatment) or to another medical condition.

Manic episode.timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with mixed features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 4 consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) have persisted, represent a noticeable change from usual behavior, and have been present to a significant degree:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation.
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharacteristic of the individual when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance in mood and the change in functioning are observable by others.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. If there are psychotic features, the episode is, by definition, manic.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or another medical condition.

Psychotic features.title: Psychotic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of delusions and/or hallucinations occurring during a mood episode.
subcriteria: 1. Delusions (false, fixed beliefs not amenable to reason or contradictory evidence).
2. Hallucinations (perceptions without external stimulus, such as hearing voices or seeing things that are not present).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Psychotic features occur exclusively during the course of a mood episode (e.g., major depressive or manic episode).

associatedFeatures: Indicates a more severe mood episode
May be associated with greater functional impairment

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A term used in diagnosis to provide additional detail about the nature, course, severity, or features of a disorder.

With anxious distress.title: With Anxious Distress (Specifier for Depressive and Bipolar Disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of at least two of the following symptoms during the majority of days of a depressive or mood episode:
subcriteria: 1. Feeling keyed up or tense.
2. Feeling unusually restless.
3. Difficulty concentrating because of worry.
4. Fear that something awful may happen.
5. Feeling that the individual might lose control of themselves.

With anxious distress.timeFrame: During the majority of days of the current or most recent episode of depression or mood disturbance.
associatedFeatures: Prominent anxiety symptoms during a mood episode
Greater severity of depressive or mood symptoms

With mixed features.title: Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition, With Mixed Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical presentation meets criteria for a bipolar and related disorder due to another medical condition, and, in addition to manic or hypomanic symptoms, symptoms of depression are also present but do not predominate.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual has experienced at least four mood episodes (manic, hypomanic, or depressive) within a 12-month period.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: One of the following is present during the most severe period of the current episode:
subcriteria: 1. Loss of pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
2. Lack of reactivity to usually pleasurable stimuli (does not feel much better, even temporarily, when something good happens).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Three (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Distinct quality of depressed mood (profound despondency, despair, and/or moroseness or empty mood).
2. Depression regularly worse in the morning.
3. Early-morning awakening (at least 2 hours before usual time of awakening).
4. Marked psychomotor agitation or retardation.
5. Significant anorexia or weight loss.
6. Excessive or inappropriate guilt.

With atypical features.title: With atypical features (specifier for mood episodes)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Mood reactivity (i.e., mood brightens in response to actual or potential positive events).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Two (or more) of the following features:
subcriteria: 1. Significant weight gain or increase in appetite.
2. Hypersomnia.
3. Leaden paralysis (i.e., heavy, leaden feelings in arms or legs).
4. A long-standing pattern of interpersonal rejection sensitivity (not limited to episodes of mood disturbance) that results in significant social or occupational impairment.

With mood-congruent psychotic features.title: With mood-congruent psychotic features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Psychotic features (delusions or hallucinations) are present during the mood episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The content of all delusions and hallucinations is consistent with the typical themes of the individual's mood episode (e.g., grandiosity or invulnerability during mania; themes of personal inadequacy, guilt, disease, death, nihilism, or deserved punishment during depression).

associatedFeatures: Psychotic symptoms that reinforce or amplify mood-congruent themes
differentialDiagnosis: Mood Disorder with mood-incongruent psychotic features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Psychotic features (delusions or hallucinations) are present during the mood episode.
subcriteria: 1. The content of all delusions and hallucinations is inconsistent with the typical themes of the individual's mood episode (e.g., depressive themes in depression, grandiosity in mania).
2. Psychotic content may include persecutory delusions, delusions of control, thought insertion, or other content not directly related to mood.

With catatonia.title: With Catatonia (Specifier)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual exhibits catatonic symptoms in addition to the primary disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Marked psychomotor disturbances are present, such as stupor, mutism, or excessive motor activity, during a mood episode.

associatedFeatures: Catatonic symptoms may include stupor, mutism, negativism, posturing, or stereotyped movements.

With peripartum onset.title: With peripartum onset

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The onset of mood symptoms occurs during pregnancy or within four weeks following delivery.

With peripartum onset.timeFrame: During pregnancy or within 4 weeks postpartum

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Mood episodes regularly occur at a particular time of year.

Euphoric mood.title: Euphoric Mood

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An excessively cheerful, high, or 'on top of the world' mood that is disproportionate to the circumstances.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by increased energy, decreased need for sleep, or grandiosity.

Lability.title: Lability

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Rapid and frequent shifts in mood.
subcriteria: 1. Alternating between euphoria.
2. Alternating between dysphoria.
3. Alternating between irritability.

associatedFeatures: Emotional responses may appear exaggerated or unpredictable.
Mood changes may be triggered by minimal or no apparent stimuli.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A symptom in which an individual feels rested after significantly less sleep than usual, without feeling tired.

Pressured speech.title: Pressured Speech

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Speech is rapid, loud, and difficult to interrupt.
subcriteria: 1. Speech is often excessive in amount.
2. Speech may be intrusive or inappropriate to the context.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by flight of ideas.

Flight of ideas.title: Flight of Ideas

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A nearly continuous flow of accelerated speech with abrupt shifts from one topic to another, reflecting racing thoughts.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in manic episodes.
Speech may be difficult to interrupt.

Goal-directed activity.title: Goal-Directed Activity (as a Symptom Feature)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Purposeful activity that is focused on achieving specific objectives.
subcriteria: 1. May manifest as increased activity in social, work, school, or sexual domains.
2. Often observed during certain mood episodes (e.g., mania or hypomania).

associatedFeatures: May contribute to excessive involvement in activities with potential for negative consequences

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Excessive motor activity associated with a feeling of inner tension.
subcriteria: 1. The activity is observable by others and not merely a subjective feeling.
2. Observable restlessness, such as inability to sit still, pacing, or hand-wringing.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Engages in potentially harmful behaviors without regard for consequences.
subcriteria: 1. Spending sprees.
2. Risky sexual behavior.
3. Foolish business investments.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of delusions or hallucinations during a mood episode.
subcriteria: 1. The content of the psychotic features is consistent with the typical themes of the mood episode (e.g., personal inadequacy, guilt, disease, death, nihilism, or deserved punishment during depression).

Mood-incongruent psychotic features.title: Mood-Incongruent Psychotic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of delusions or hallucinations during a mood episode.
subcriteria: 1. The content of the psychotic symptoms does not involve typical depressive or manic themes (e.g., guilt, disease, death, nihilism, deserved punishment, or themes of grandiosity, inflated worth, or power).
2. The psychotic content is inconsistent with the mood episode or is a mixture of mood-incongruent and mood-congruent themes.

associatedFeatures: Psychotic symptoms whose content is not consistent with the typical themes of a mood episode

Catatonia.title: Catatonia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical picture is dominated by three (or more) of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Stupor (i.e., no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment)
2. Catalepsy (i.e., passive induction of a posture held against gravity)
3. Waxy flexibility (i.e., slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner)
4. Mutism (i.e., no, or very little, verbal response [exclude if known aphasia])
5. Negativism (i.e., opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli)
6. Posturing (i.e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity)
7. Mannerism (i.e., odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions)
8. Stereotypy (i.e., repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements)
9. Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
10. Grimacing
11. Echolalia (i.e., mimicking another's speech)
12. Echopraxia (i.e., mimicking another's movements)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The catatonic features are present during most of the mood episode, medical condition, or psychotic disorder.

specifiers: With catatonia (as a specifier for mood episodes, psychotic disorders, or due to a medical condition)
comorbidity: Mood disorders (e.g., Major Depressive Episode, Bipolar Disorder)
Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Some symptoms of a mood episode are present, but the full criteria for the mood episode are no longer met.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: No significant symptoms of a mood episode remain.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A descriptive term added to a diagnosis to provide further detail, but not associated with a specific diagnostic code.

Criterion A.title: Schizophrenia and Related Disorders; Mood Episodes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A diagnostic requirement for schizophrenia and related disorders, typically involving the presence of key psychotic symptoms such as delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized speech. The primary diagnostic requirement for a mood episode, typically involving a distinct change in mood and activity or energy.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Delusions or hallucinations must be present for at least 2 weeks in the absence of a major mood episode (depressive or manic) during the lifetime duration of the illness.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Mood symptoms meeting criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the active and residual portions of the illness.
subcriteria: 1. The mood episode causes marked impairment in functioning or necessitates hospitalization.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

Mixed Features.title: With Mixed Features (Specifier)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual currently meets criteria for a manic, hypomanic, or major depressive episode, and at the same time, at least three symptoms of the opposite pole are present during the majority of days of the current or most recent episode.
subcriteria: 1. During a manic or hypomanic episode, at least three depressive symptoms are present.
2. During a major depressive episode, at least three manic/hypomanic symptoms are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mixed symptoms represent a noticeable change from the individual's usual behavior.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, medication, or other treatment).

Mixed Features.timeFrame: Present during the majority of days of the current or most recent mood episode.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Rapid Cycling.title: Rapid Cycling Specifier for Bipolar I or II Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: At least four mood episodes (manic, hypomanic, or major depressive) have occurred during the previous 12 months.
subcriteria: 1. Episodes are demarcated by either a period of full or partial remission of at least 2 months or a switch to an episode of opposite polarity (e.g., from a depressive episode to a manic episode).

Mood-Incongruent Psychotic Features.title: Mood-Incongruent Psychotic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of psychotic symptoms (delusions or hallucinations) during a mood episode.
subcriteria: 1. The content of the psychotic symptoms is inconsistent with the typical mood-congruent themes (e.g., guilt, disease, death, nihilism, deserved punishment for depression; inflated worth, power, knowledge, identity, or special relationship to a deity or famous person for mania).
2. The psychotic content may include a mixture of mood-congruent and mood-incongruent themes.

associatedFeatures: Increased likelihood of diagnosis with a psychotic disorder

Euthymic Period.title: Euthymic Period

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period during which mood symptoms (e.g., depression, mania, hypomania) are absent.
subcriteria: 1. The individual's mood is stable and within the normal range.
2. The individual is at their baseline level of functioning.

Euthymic Period.timeFrame: No minimum duration specified; refers to periods between mood episodes.
associatedFeatures: Absence of clinically significant mood symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The co-occurrence of two or more disorders, conditions, or illnesses in the same individual, either simultaneously or sequentially.

Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar Dis.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and Related Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, with or without depressed mood, or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both:
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the symptoms in Criterion A.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a bipolar or related disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent bipolar disorder could include: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence suggesting the existence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced bipolar and related disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may be accompanied by psychotic features.
Symptoms typically resolve with cessation of substance/medication use.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The process of distinguishing a particular disease or condition from others that present with similar clinical features.

Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder.title: Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development, as characterized by (1) and/or (2):
subcriteria: 1. Inattention: Six (or more) of the following symptoms have persisted for at least 6 months to a degree that is inconsistent with developmental level and that negatively impacts directly on social and academic/occupational activities: (a) Often fails to give close attention to details or makes careless mistakes in schoolwork, at work, or during other activities. (b) Often has difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities. (c) Often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly. (d) Often does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace. (e) Often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities. (f) Often avoids, dislikes, or is reluctant to engage in tasks that require sustained mental effort. (g) Often loses things necessary for tasks or activities. (h) Is often easily distracted by extraneous stimuli. (i) Is often forgetful in daily activities.

2. Hyperactivity and Impulsivity: Six (or more) of the following symptoms have persisted for at least 6 months to a degree that is inconsistent with developmental level and that negatively impacts directly on social and academic/occupational activities: (a) Often fidgets with or taps hands or feet or squirms in seat. (b) Often leaves seat in situations when remaining seated is expected. (c) Often runs about or climbs in situations where it is inappropriate. (d) Often unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly. (e) Is often 'on the go,' acting as if 'driven by a motor.' (f) Often talks excessively. (g) Often blurts out an answer before a question has been completed. (h) Often has difficulty waiting his or her turn. (i) Often interrupts or intrudes on others.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms were present prior to age 12 years.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms are present in two or more settings (e.g., at home, school, or work; with friends or relatives; in other activities).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: There is clear evidence that the symptoms interfere with, or reduce the quality of, social, academic, or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The symptoms do not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder and are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder, anxiety disorder, dissociative disorder, personality disorder, substance intoxication or withdrawal).

Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder.timeFrame: Symptoms have persisted for at least 6 months.

Personality Disorder.title: Personality Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An enduring pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture.
subcriteria: 1. Manifested in two (or more) of the following areas: cognition, affectivity, interpersonal functioning, or impulse control.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is inflexible and pervasive across a broad range of personal and social situations.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The enduring pattern leads to clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The pattern is stable and of long duration, and its onset can be traced back at least to adolescence or early adulthood.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is not better explained as a manifestation or consequence of another mental disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Personality Disorder.timeFrame: Onset can be traced back at least to adolescence or early adulthood

Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder.title: Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Severe recurrent temper outbursts manifested verbally (e.g., verbal rages) and/or behaviorally (e.g., physical aggression toward people or property) that are grossly out of proportion in intensity or duration to the situation or provocation.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The temper outbursts are inconsistent with developmental level.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The temper outbursts occur, on average, three or more times per week.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The mood between temper outbursts is persistently irritable or angry most of the day, nearly every day, and is observable by others (e.g., parents, teachers, peers).

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Criteria A–D have been present for 12 or more months. Throughout that time, the individual has not had a period lasting 3 or more consecutive months without all of the symptoms in Criteria A–D.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: Criteria A and D are present in at least two of three settings (i.e., at home, at school, with peers) and are severe in at least one of these.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The diagnosis should not be made for the first time before age 6 years or after age 18 years.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: By history or observation, the age at onset of Criteria A–E is before 10 years.

criteria.label: I
criteria.text: There has never been a distinct period lasting more than 1 day during which the full symptom criteria, except duration, for a manic or hypomanic episode have been met.

criteria.label: J
criteria.text: The behaviors do not occur exclusively during an episode of major depressive disorder and are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., autism spectrum disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, separation anxiety disorder, persistent depressive disorder [dysthymia]).

criteria.label: K
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or to another medical or neurological condition.

Disruptive Mood Dysregulation Disorder.timeFrame: At least 12 months, with no period of 3 or more consecutive months without all symptoms.
associatedFeatures: Marked disruption in family and peer relationships
Increased risk for depressive and anxiety disorders in adulthood

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A cluster of metabolic abnormalities, with at least three of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Increased blood pressure (≥130/85 mmHg or on antihypertensive medication)
2. Elevated fasting blood sugar (≥100 mg/dL or on medication for hyperglycemia)
3. Excess body fat around the waist (waist circumference ≥102 cm in men or ≥88 cm in women)
4. Abnormal cholesterol levels (triglycerides ≥150 mg/dL or on medication for elevated triglycerides)
5. Low high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol (<40 mg/dL in men or <50 mg/dL in women or on medication for reduced HDL)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The above conditions occur together, increasing the risk of cardiovascular disease, stroke, and diabetes.

Migraine.title: Migraine

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent episodes of moderate to severe headache, lasting 4–72 hours (when untreated or unsuccessfully treated), fulfilling criteria B–D.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Headache has at least two of the following characteristics:
subcriteria: 1. Unilateral location
2. Pulsating quality
3. Moderate or severe pain intensity
4. Aggravation by or causing avoidance of routine physical activity (e.g., walking or climbing stairs)

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During headache at least one of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Nausea and/or vomiting
2. Photophobia and phonophobia

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Not better explained by another ICHD-3 diagnosis.

associatedFeatures: Prodromal symptoms (e.g., mood changes, food cravings)

Flight of Ideas.title: Flight of Ideas

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Rapid and continuous flow of speech with abrupt changes from topic to topic, usually based on understandable associations.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Most commonly observed during manic episodes.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by increased distractibility and pressured speech.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a return to the individual's previous level of social, occupational, or educational functioning following a mood episode.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a likelihood that an individual will attempt or die by suicide.
subcriteria: 1. Risk is high in individuals with bipolar II disorder, with a significant proportion reporting suicide attempts.
2. Individuals with depressive disorders may attempt or complete suicide, with risk influenced by the disorder or its treatment.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Negative outcomes that may result from excessive involvement in risky activities.
subcriteria: 1. Unrestrained spending.
2. Sexual indiscretions.
3. Foolish business investments.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A clear and noticeable alteration in an individual's usual behavior or ability to function, which is uncharacteristic when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms or changes in mood and functioning are present and can be noticed by people other than the individual experiencing them.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A significant disruption in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Physiological effects of a substance.title: Physiological Effects of a Substance

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of changes in mood, behavior, or physical/mental functioning that are directly attributable to the recent use of, or withdrawal from, a drug, medication, or other substance.
subcriteria: 1. The disturbance developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the observed symptoms.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a primary psychiatric disorder (i.e., the symptoms are not present in the absence of substance use or withdrawal).

associatedFeatures: Physical symptoms such as changes in heart rate, blood pressure, or motor activity
Mental status changes including confusion, agitation, or mood lability
differentialDiagnosis: Primary psychiatric disorders (e.g., Major Depressive Disorder, Bipolar Disorder)
Medical conditions unrelated to substance use

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day, as indicated by either subjective report or observation made by others.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others, not merely subjective feelings of restlessness or being slowed down).
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Loss of interest or pleasure.title: Loss of Interest or Pleasure (Anhedonia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. A marked decrease in enjoyment or interest in almost all activities, nearly every day.
2. A marked reduction in interest or enjoyment in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.

Loss of interest or pleasure.timeFrame: Most of the day, nearly every day

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Noticeable weight loss or gain (e.g., more than 5% of body weight in a month) or a significant change in appetite nearly every day.

Insomnia.title: Insomnia Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A predominant complaint of dissatisfaction with sleep quantity or quality, associated with one (or more) of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Difficulty initiating sleep.
2. Difficulty maintaining sleep, characterized by frequent awakenings or problems returning to sleep after awakenings.
3. Early-morning awakening with inability to return to sleep.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The sleep disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, educational, academic, behavioral, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The sleep difficulty occurs at least 3 nights per week.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The sleep difficulty is present for at least 3 months.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The sleep difficulty occurs despite adequate opportunity for sleep.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The insomnia is not better explained by and does not occur exclusively during the course of another sleep-wake disorder.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The insomnia is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication).

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: Coexisting mental disorders and medical conditions do not adequately explain the predominant complaint of insomnia.

differentialDiagnosis: Other sleep-wake disorders (e.g., narcolepsy, circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders)
Mental disorders (e.g., depressive disorders, anxiety disorders)

Hypersomnia.title: Hypersomnia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Excessive sleepiness or sleeping much more than usual, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Excessive sleep, either as an extended period of nighttime sleep or daytime napping, totaling at least 10 hours per day or at least 2 hours more than usual when not depressed.

associatedFeatures: Impaired social or occupational functioning due to excessive sleep

Psychomotor retardation.title: Psychomotor Retardation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Observable slowing of thought and physical movement.
subcriteria: 1. Observable slowing of speech.
2. Observable slowing of thinking.
3. Observable slowing of body movements.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The slowing is observable by others and is not limited to subjective feelings.

associatedFeatures: May be present in mood disorders such as major depressive disorder.
Can be accompanied by diminished facial expression and reduced gesturing.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A nearly daily experience of tiredness or loss of energy.
subcriteria: 1. Persistent feeling of tiredness or lack of energy not relieved by rest.

Feelings of worthlessness.title: Feelings of Worthlessness

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent and excessive feelings of being unworthy or guilty, which may be delusional and occur nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Unrealistically negative evaluations of one's own value or self-worth.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by delusional guilt or self-reproach

Diminished ability to think or concentra.title: Diminished Ability to Think or Concentrate

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A reduced capacity to focus, think clearly, or make decisions, occurring nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. The diminished ability is noticeable either by the individual or by others.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Difficulty making decisions, experienced nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Difficulty making decisions is either reported by the individual or observed by others.

Recurrent thoughts of death.title: Recurrent Thoughts of Death

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of recurrent thoughts about death, not limited to fear of dying.
subcriteria: 1. Recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan.
2. A suicide attempt.
3. A specific plan for committing suicide.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by feelings of hopelessness or worthlessness.
Often occurs in the context of mood disorders such as Major Depressive Disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
subcriteria: 1. A level of emotional or behavioral disturbance that causes substantial problems in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
2. A level of emotional or functional disturbance that interferes with social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
3. Symptoms that cause substantial emotional suffering or interfere with social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Schizoaffective disorder.title: Schizoaffective Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An uninterrupted period of illness during which there is a major mood episode (major depressive or manic) concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia.
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Delusions or hallucinations for 2 or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode (depressive or manic) during the lifetime duration of the illness.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Symptoms that meet criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the active and residual portions of the illness.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Schizoaffective disorder.timeFrame: Delusions or hallucinations must be present for 2 or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Schizophrenia.title: Schizophrenia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Two (or more) of the following, each present for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated). At least one of these must be (1), (2), or (3):
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: For a significant portion of the time since the onset of the disturbance, level of functioning in one or more major areas such as work, interpersonal relations, or self-care is markedly below the level achieved prior to the onset.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Continuous signs of the disturbance persist for at least 6 months. This 6-month period must include at least 1 month of symptoms (or less if successfully treated) that meet Criterion A (i.e., active-phase symptoms) and may include periods of prodromal or residual symptoms.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out because either (1) no major depressive or manic episodes have occurred concurrently with the active-phase symptoms, or (2) if mood episodes have occurred during active-phase symptoms, they have been present for a minority of the total duration of the active and residual periods of the illness.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: If there is a history of autism spectrum disorder or a communication disorder of childhood onset, the additional diagnosis of schizophrenia is made only if prominent delusions or hallucinations, in addition to the other required symptoms of schizophrenia, are also present for at least 1 month (or less if successfully treated).

Schizophrenia.timeFrame: Continuous signs of the disturbance persist for at least 6 months, including at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms.
specifiers: first episode, currently in acute episode
first episode, currently in partial remission
first episode, currently in full remission
multiple episodes, currently in acute episode
multiple episodes, currently in partial remission
multiple episodes, currently in full remission
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

Schizophreniform disorder.title: Schizophreniform Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Two (or more) of the following, each present for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated). At least one of these must be (1), (2), or (3):
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: An episode of the disorder lasts at least 1 month but less than 6 months. When diagnosis must be made without waiting for recovery, it should be qualified as 'provisional.'

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out because either (1) no major depressive or manic episodes have occurred concurrently with the active-phase symptoms, or (2) if mood episodes have occurred during active-phase symptoms, they have been present for a minority of the total duration of the active and residual periods of the illness.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

Schizophreniform disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 month but less than 6 months
associatedFeatures: Impaired social or occupational functioning may be present but is not required.
Cognitive and perceptual disturbances similar to those seen in schizophrenia.
differentialDiagnosis: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Delusional disorder.title: Delusional Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

associatedFeatures: Legal difficulties related to delusional content
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Rapid cycling.title: Rapid Cycling Specifier for Bipolar Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The occurrence of at least four mood episodes in the previous 12 months that meet criteria for a manic, hypomanic, or major depressive episode.

Melancholic features.title: Depressive Episode with Melancholic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: One of the following is present during the most severe period of the current episode:
subcriteria: 1. Loss of pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
2. Lack of reactivity to usually pleasurable stimuli (does not feel much better, even temporarily, when something good happens).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Three (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Distinct quality of depressed mood (profound despondency, despair, or moroseness, or the mood is different from that experienced after the loss of a loved one).
2. Depression regularly worse in the morning.
3. Early-morning awakening (at least 2 hours before usual time of awakening).
4. Marked psychomotor agitation or retardation.
5. Significant anorexia or weight loss.
6. Excessive or inappropriate guilt.

differentialDiagnosis: Mood disorder due to another medical condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Mood reactivity (i.e., mood brightens in response to actual or potential positive events) is present during the majority of days of the current or most recent major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Two (or more) of the following features are present:
subcriteria: 1. Significant weight gain or increase in appetite.
2. Hypersomnia.
3. Leaden paralysis (i.e., heavy, leaden feelings in arms or legs).
4. A long-standing pattern of interpersonal rejection sensitivity (not limited to episodes of mood disturbance) that results in significant social or occupational impairment.

Peripartum onset.title: Peripartum Onset Specifier

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The onset of mood symptoms occurs during pregnancy or within four weeks following delivery.

Peripartum onset.timeFrame: During pregnancy or within four weeks postpartum

Seasonal pattern.title: Seasonal Pattern (Specifier for Mood Episodes)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There has been a regular temporal relationship between the onset of mood episodes and a particular time of the year (e.g., fall or winter).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Full remissions (or a change from depression to mania or hypomania) also occur at a characteristic time of year (e.g., spring).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: In the last two years, the pattern has occurred without nonseasonal episodes of the mood disturbance.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The seasonal episodes substantially outnumber any nonseasonal episodes that may have occurred over the individual's lifetime.

Seasonal pattern.timeFrame: Pattern persists for at least two years.
associatedFeatures: May include atypical depressive symptoms such as hypersomnia, increased appetite, and weight gain during depressive episodes.
differentialDiagnosis: Mood disorder due to another medical condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Few, if any, symptoms beyond those required to make the diagnosis are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms are distressing but manageable.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: There is only minor impairment in social or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The number of symptoms, their intensity, and/or the degree of functional impairment is between those specified for 'mild' and 'severe.'

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The number of symptoms is substantially in excess of those required to make the diagnosis.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms are seriously distressing and unmanageable.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: There is marked interference with social and occupational functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A state of normal mood, neither depressed nor elevated.

Substance/medication-induced depressive.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both:
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the symptoms in Criterion A.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a depressive disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent depressive disorder could include the following: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence suggesting the existence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced depressive disorder (e.g., a history of recurrent non–substance/medication-related episodes).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Substance/medication-induced depressive.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or soon after substance intoxication, withdrawal, or exposure.
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Substance/medication-induced bipolar and.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and Related Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, with or without depressed mood, or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both (1) and (2):
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the symptoms in Criterion A.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a bipolar or related disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent bipolar or related disorder could include: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period of time (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence suggesting the existence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced bipolar and related disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may be accompanied by psychotic features.
Symptoms typically resolve with cessation of substance/medication use.
differentialDiagnosis: Substance intoxication or withdrawal with mood features

Depressive and related disorder due to a.title: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, with depressed mood, in which the stressor is a serious medical condition).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

comorbidity: Other medical conditions (e.g., stroke, Parkinson’s disease)

Bipolar and related disorder due to anot.title: Bipolar and related disorder due to another medical condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally increased activity or energy that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, delirium).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning, or necessitates hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may fluctuate with the course of the medical condition
May include irritability, increased goal-directed activity, or decreased need for sleep
comorbidity: Other mental disorders due to another medical condition

Mixed features.title: Major Depressive Episode with Mixed Features Specifier

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The current or most recent episode of major depression is characterized by the presence of at least three manic or hypomanic symptoms during the majority of days of the depressive episode.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms are observable by others and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior.
2. Symptoms do not meet full criteria for a manic or hypomanic episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mixed features specifier may also be applied to mood episodes where symptoms of the opposite mood pole are present (e.g., depressive symptoms during hypomania or hypomanic symptoms during depression).

Mixed features.timeFrame: During the majority of days of the current or most recent episode of depression.
associatedFeatures: Increased risk for developing bipolar disorder

Unpredictable mood changes.title: Unpredictable Mood Changes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Frequent and erratic shifts in mood that are not attributable to a general medical condition or substance use.
subcriteria: 1. Mood changes occur multiple times within a day or over several days.
2. Mood shifts are observed by others and interfere with interpersonal or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mood changes cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., Bipolar Disorder, Borderline Personality Disorder), a medical condition, or the physiological effects of a substance.

Unpredictable mood changes.timeFrame: Present for at least several weeks.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A tendency to act quickly without careful thought, often leading to risky behaviors.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of symptoms such as delusions or hallucinations that indicate a loss of contact with reality.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: These symptoms do not occur during hypomanic episodes in bipolar II disorder.

Nonepisodic Irritability.title: Nonepisodic Irritability

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent irritability that does not occur in distinct episodes.

associatedFeatures: In youth, associated with increased risk for anxiety and depressive disorders.

Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychot.title: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following domains of abnormality:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized thinking (speech)
4. Grossly disorganized or abnormal motor behavior (including catatonia)
5. Negative symptoms

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Psychotic symptoms occur independently of mood episodes.

associatedFeatures: May include cognitive deficits, social and occupational dysfunction, and impaired insight.
differentialDiagnosis: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Panic Disorder.title: Panic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent unexpected panic attacks. A panic attack is an abrupt surge of intense fear or intense discomfort that reaches a peak within minutes, and during which time four (or more) of the following symptoms occur:
subcriteria: 1. Palpitations, pounding heart, or accelerated heart rate
2. Sweating
3. Trembling or shaking
4. Sensations of shortness of breath or smothering
5. Feelings of choking
6. Chest pain or discomfort
7. Nausea or abdominal distress
8. Feeling dizzy, unsteady, light-headed, or faint
9. Chills or heat sensations
10. Paresthesias (numbness or tingling sensations)
11. Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (being detached from oneself)
12. Fear of losing control or 'going crazy'
13. Fear of dying

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: At least one of the attacks has been followed by 1 month (or more) of one or both of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Persistent concern or worry about additional panic attacks or their consequences (e.g., losing control, having a heart attack, 'going crazy')
2. A significant maladaptive change in behavior related to the attacks (e.g., behaviors designed to avoid having panic attacks, such as avoidance of exercise or unfamiliar situations)

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism, cardiopulmonary disorders).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., the panic attacks do not occur only in response to feared social situations, as in social anxiety disorder; in response to circumscribed phobic objects or situations, as in specific phobia; in response to obsessions, as in obsessive-compulsive disorder; in response to reminders of traumatic events, as in posttraumatic stress disorder; or in response to separation from attachment figures, as in separation anxiety disorder).

Panic Disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 month of persistent concern or maladaptive behavior following an attack
differentialDiagnosis: Other specified and unspecified anxiety disorders
Medical conditions (e.g., cardiac, respiratory, vestibular, gastrointestinal)
Other mental disorders with panic attacks (e.g., social anxiety disorder, specific phobia, PTSD, OCD)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A problematic pattern of substance use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by at least two of the following, occurring within a 12-month period:
subcriteria: 1. The substance is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended.
2. There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use.
3. A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain, use, or recover from the substance’s effects.
4. Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use the substance.
5. Recurrent substance use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home.
