6. Continued substance use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of the substance.
7. Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of substance use.
8. Recurrent substance use in situations in which it is physically hazardous.
9. Substance use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by the substance.

10. Tolerance, as defined by either: (a) a need for markedly increased amounts of the substance to achieve intoxication or desired effect, or (b) a markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of the substance.
11. Withdrawal, as manifested by either: (a) the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance, or (b) the substance is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms.

Creativity.title: Creativity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The ability to produce original and valuable ideas.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: In some individuals with bipolar disorder, heightened creativity may be observed, particularly during hypomanic episodes.

associatedFeatures: Heightened creativity may be associated with mood elevation, increased goal-directed activity, and reduced need for sleep during hypomanic episodes.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The likely course and outcome of a disorder, including chances of recovery and recurrence.

Bipolar II disorder.title: Bipolar II Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria have been met for at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The occurrence of the hypomanic episode(s) and major depressive episode(s) is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms of depression or the unpredictability caused by frequent alternation between periods of depression and hypomania causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Bipolar II disorder.timeFrame: Major depressive episode: at least two weeks; hypomanic episode: at least four consecutive days.
associatedFeatures: Increased risk of suicide, especially during depressive episodes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of significant feelings of anxiety and fear that are excessive or persistent and interfere with daily functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A problematic pattern of substance use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by at least two of the following, occurring within a 12-month period:
subcriteria: 1. The substance is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended.
2. There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use.
3. A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain, use, or recover from the effects of the substance.
4. Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use the substance.
5. Recurrent substance use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home.
6. Continued substance use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of the substance.
7. Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of substance use.
8. Recurrent substance use in situations in which it is physically hazardous.
9. Substance use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by the substance.

10. Tolerance, as defined by either of the following: (a) a need for markedly increased amounts of the substance to achieve intoxication or desired effect; (b) a markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of the substance.

11. Withdrawal, as manifested by either of the following: (a) the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance; (b) the substance (or a closely related substance) is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent disturbance of eating or eating-related behavior that results in the altered consumption or absorption of food and that significantly impairs physical health or psychosocial functioning.

Binge-eating disorder.title: Binge-Eating Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Eating, in a discrete period of time (e.g., within any 2-hour period), an amount of food that is definitely larger than what most people would eat in a similar period of time under similar circumstances.
2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The binge-eating episodes are associated with three (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Eating much more rapidly than normal.
2. Eating until feeling uncomfortably full.
3. Eating large amounts of food when not feeling physically hungry.
4. Eating alone because of feeling embarrassed by how much one is eating.
5. Feeling disgusted with oneself, depressed, or very guilty afterward.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Marked distress regarding binge eating is present.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The binge eating occurs, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The binge eating is not associated with the recurrent use of inappropriate compensatory behavior as in bulimia nervosa and does not occur exclusively during the course of bulimia nervosa or anorexia nervosa.

Binge-eating disorder.timeFrame: At least once a week for 3 months
specifiers: extreme (14 or more episodes per week)
associatedFeatures: Feelings of distress, shame, or guilt about eating behaviors
Possible history of dieting or weight fluctuations

Bulimia nervosa.title: Bulimia Nervosa

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent episodes of binge eating. An episode of binge eating is characterized by both of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Eating, in a discrete period of time (e.g., within any 2-hour period), an amount of food that is definitely larger than what most individuals would eat in a similar period of time under similar circumstances.
2. A sense of lack of control over eating during the episode (e.g., a feeling that one cannot stop eating or control what or how much one is eating).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors in order to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting; misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or other medications; fasting; or excessive exercise.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The binge eating and inappropriate compensatory behaviors both occur, on average, at least once a week for 3 months.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Self-evaluation is unduly influenced by body shape and weight.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during episodes of anorexia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa.timeFrame: At least once a week for 3 months
associatedFeatures: Feelings of shame or guilt after binge episodes
Preoccupation with body shape and weight

Anorexia nervosa.title: Anorexia Nervosa

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Restriction of energy intake relative to requirements, leading to a significantly low body weight in the context of age, sex, developmental trajectory, and physical health.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Intense fear of gaining weight or of becoming fat, or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Disturbance in the way in which one’s body weight or shape is experienced, undue influence of body weight or shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight.

associatedFeatures: Physical signs such as amenorrhea, bradycardia, hypotension, hypothermia, and lanugo
differentialDiagnosis: Medical conditions (e.g., gastrointestinal diseases, endocrine disorders)

Cyclothymic disorder.title: Cyclothymic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: For at least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents) there have been numerous periods with hypomanic symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode and numerous periods with depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the above 2-year period (1 year in children and adolescents), the hypomanic and depressive periods have been present for at least half the time and the individual has not been without the symptoms for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive, manic, or hypomanic episode have never been met.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms in Criterion A are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism).

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Cyclothymic disorder.timeFrame: At least 2 years (at least 1 year in children and adolescents)
associatedFeatures: Increased risk for developing bipolar I or II disorder

Hypomanic symptoms.title: Hypomanic Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 4 consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep.
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation.
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharacteristic of the individual when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance in mood and the change in functioning are observable by others.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. If there are psychotic features, the episode is, by definition, manic.

associatedFeatures: Symptoms similar to mania but less severe, including elevated or irritable mood, increased activity or energy, but not causing marked impairment.

Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychot.title: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized thinking (speech)
4. Grossly disorganized or abnormal motor behavior (including catatonia)
5. Negative symptoms (e.g., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Hyperthyroidism.title: Hyperthyroidism

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Evidence of an overactive thyroid gland, as indicated by elevated levels of thyroid hormones (e.g., thyroxine [T4], triiodothyronine [T3]) on laboratory testing.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The excessive thyroid hormone production is associated with physiological and/or psychological symptoms, which may include mood changes (e.g., anxiety, irritability), weight loss, increased appetite, palpitations, heat intolerance, and tremor.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another medical condition or the physiological effects of a substance.

associatedFeatures: Mood changes such as anxiety or irritability
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with anxious distress

Borderline personality disorder.title: Borderline Personality Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive pattern of instability of interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, and marked impulsivity, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment.
2. A pattern of unstable and intense interpersonal relationships characterized by alternating between extremes of idealization and devaluation.
3. Identity disturbance: markedly and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self.
4. Impulsivity in at least two areas that are potentially self-damaging (e.g., spending, sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating).
5. Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, or threats, or self-mutilating behavior.
6. Affective instability due to a marked reactivity of mood (e.g., intense episodic dysphoria, irritability, or anxiety usually lasting a few hours and only rarely more than a few days).
7. Chronic feelings of emptiness.
8. Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty controlling anger (e.g., frequent displays of temper, constant anger, recurrent physical fights).
9. Transient, stress-related paranoid ideation or severe dissociative symptoms.

Borderline personality disorder.timeFrame: Beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts.
differentialDiagnosis: Other Personality Disorders (e.g., Histrionic, Narcissistic, Antisocial)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity-impulsivity that interferes with functioning or development, as characterized by (1) and/or (2):
subcriteria: 1. Inattention: Six (or more) of the following symptoms have persisted for at least 6 months to a degree that is inconsistent with developmental level and that negatively impacts directly on social and academic/occupational activities: (a) Often fails to give close attention to details or makes careless mistakes in schoolwork, at work, or during other activities. (b) Often has difficulty sustaining attention in tasks or play activities. (c) Often does not seem to listen when spoken to directly. (d) Often does not follow through on instructions and fails to finish schoolwork, chores, or duties in the workplace. (e) Often has difficulty organizing tasks and activities. (f) Often avoids, dislikes, or is reluctant to engage in tasks that require sustained mental effort. (g) Often loses things necessary for tasks or activities. (h) Is often easily distracted by extraneous stimuli. (i) Is often forgetful in daily activities.

2. Hyperactivity and Impulsivity: Six (or more) of the following symptoms have persisted for at least 6 months to a degree that is inconsistent with developmental level and that negatively impacts directly on social and academic/occupational activities: (a) Often fidgets with or taps hands or feet or squirms in seat. (b) Often leaves seat in situations when remaining seated is expected. (c) Often runs about or climbs in situations where it is inappropriate. (d) Often unable to play or engage in leisure activities quietly. (e) Is often 'on the go,' acting as if 'driven by a motor.' (f) Often talks excessively. (g) Often blurts out an answer before a question has been completed. (h) Often has difficulty waiting his or her turn. (i) Often interrupts or intrudes on others.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms were present prior to age 12 years.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Several inattentive or hyperactive-impulsive symptoms are present in two or more settings (e.g., at home, school, or work; with friends or relatives; in other activities).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: There is clear evidence that the symptoms interfere with, or reduce the quality of, social, academic, or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The symptoms do not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder and are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder, anxiety disorder, dissociative disorder, personality disorder, substance intoxication or withdrawal).

Delirium.title: Delirium

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a disturbance in attention (i.e., reduced ability to direct, focus, sustain, and shift attention) and awareness (reduced orientation to the environment).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance develops over a short period of time (usually hours to a few days), represents an acute change from baseline attention and awareness, and tends to fluctuate in severity during the course of a day.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: An additional disturbance in cognition (e.g., memory deficit, disorientation, language, visuospatial ability, or perception) is present.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbances in Criteria A and C are not better explained by another preexisting, established, or evolving neurocognitive disorder and do not occur in the context of a severely reduced level of arousal, such as coma.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is a direct physiological consequence of another medical condition, substance intoxication or withdrawal, or exposure to a toxin, or is due to multiple etiologies.

Delirium.timeFrame: Develops over a short period (usually hours to a few days) and fluctuates during the day.
specifiers: delirium due to another medical condition
associatedFeatures: Emotional disturbances (e.g., anxiety, fear, depression, irritability, anger, euphoria, apathy)
Psychomotor disturbances (e.g., hyperactive, hypoactive, or mixed level of activity)

Mood disturbance.title: Mood Disturbance

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A significant change or abnormality in emotional state.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood (e.g., feeling sad, empty, or hopeless).
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
3. Abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood (e.g., mania or hypomania).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mood disturbance may be related to a medical or psychiatric condition.

associatedFeatures: Changes in energy or activity levels

Insidious onset.title: Insidious Onset

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Gradual and subtle development of symptoms.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms emerge over an extended period of time.
2. Early stages may be difficult to detect due to mild or nonspecific presentation.

associatedFeatures: Disorder may not be recognized until symptoms become more pronounced.
May contribute to delayed diagnosis and intervention.

Persistent course.title: Persistent Course

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pattern in which symptoms continue over a long period of time without significant remission.

Persistent course.timeFrame: Over a long period of time without significant remission

ICD-9-CM.title: International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-9-CM)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: ICD-9-CM is a coding system used for diagnosing and classifying diseases, symptoms, and procedures in clinical settings.

ICD-10-CM.title: International Classification of Diseases, Tenth Revision, Clinical Modification (ICD-10-CM)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: ICD-10-CM is a coding system used to classify and code diagnoses, symptoms, and procedures in clinical settings.

Onset during intoxication.title: Onset during Intoxication (Specifier for Substance/Medication-Induced Bipolar and Related Disorder)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The criteria are met for intoxication with a substance.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The bipolar symptoms develop during the period of intoxication, that is, while the individual is under the influence of the substance.

Onset during withdrawal.title: Onset during withdrawal (specifier)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The criteria for withdrawal from a substance are met.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Bipolar symptoms develop during or shortly after the withdrawal period.

Onset during withdrawal.timeFrame: During or shortly after the process of stopping or reducing use of a substance.
associatedFeatures: The development of symptoms while the individual is experiencing withdrawal from a substance.

Comorbid Substance Use Disorder.title: Comorbid Substance Use Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pattern of substance use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, occurring concurrently with another mental disorder.
subcriteria: 1. The substance use disorder meets full diagnostic criteria for a specific substance (e.g., alcohol, opioids, stimulants).
2. The mental disorder is not better explained by the effects of the substance (i.e., not solely substance-induced).

associatedFeatures: Potential for substance-induced mood or psychotic symptoms
differentialDiagnosis: Primary Mental Disorders without substance use

Mania.title: Manic Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep)
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli)
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments)

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or other treatment) or to another medical condition.

Mania.timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 4 consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy and activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) have persisted, represent a noticeable change from usual behavior, and have been present to a significant degree:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep)
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli)
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments)

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharacteristic of the individual when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance in mood and the change in functioning are observable by others.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. If there are psychotic features, the episode is, by definition, manic.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The cause or origin of a disease or disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Etiology often refers to the underlying medical condition responsible for psychiatric symptoms.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Particularly relevant is the relationship between a medical condition and the development of depressive symptoms.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Laboratory or clinical findings that help confirm the presence of a specific disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Objective signs, symptoms, or laboratory findings that help confirm the presence of a specific medical or psychiatric condition.

With manic features.title: Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition, With Manic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, but full criteria for a manic or hypomanic episode are not met.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning, or necessitates hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

With manic- or hypomanic-like episode.title: Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition, With Manic- or Hypomanic-Like Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally increased activity or energy that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning, or necessitates hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Instructions provided to clinicians on how to record and code a diagnosis according to classification systems like ICD-9-CM or ICD-10-CM.

Cushing’s Disease.title: Cushing’s Disease

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Prolonged exposure to elevated levels of cortisol, either endogenous or exogenous in origin.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is associated with clinically significant mood symptoms, such as mania or depression.

associatedFeatures: Weight gain, particularly in the face and trunk
Skin changes (e.g., purple striae, easy bruising)
Psychiatric symptoms including irritability, anxiety, or cognitive impairment
differentialDiagnosis: Other causes of hypercortisolism (e.g., Cushing’s syndrome due to adrenal tumor)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of a chronic disease of the central nervous system characterized by inflammation and damage to the myelin sheath.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The condition may be associated with neuropsychiatric symptoms, including mood disturbances such as mania.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A sudden interruption of blood supply to the brain, resulting in neurological deficits.
subcriteria: 1. Evidence of focal neurological impairment (e.g., weakness, numbness, speech disturbance).
2. Symptoms are consistent with acute vascular injury as confirmed by clinical assessment or neuroimaging.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance may result in psychiatric symptoms, including mood disturbances (e.g., depression, emotional lability).

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of an injury to the brain caused by an external force (e.g., blow to the head, acceleration/deceleration forces, penetration by a foreign object).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The injury results in one or more of the following cognitive, emotional, or behavioral symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Cognitive impairment (e.g., memory disturbance, attention deficits, executive dysfunction)
2. Emotional symptoms (e.g., mood lability, irritability, depression, mania or hypomania)
3. Behavioral changes (e.g., impulsivity, aggression, apathy)

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms are not better explained by another mental disorder or the direct physiological effects of a substance.

Short-Duration Hypomanic Episodes and Ma.title: Short-Duration Hypomanic Episodes and Major Depressive Episodes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A lifetime history of major depressive episodes is present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There have been two or more episodes of hypomania, each lasting only 2–3 days.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The hypomanic and major depressive episodes do not overlap in time.

Short-Duration Hypomanic Episodes and Ma.timeFrame: Hypomanic episodes last 2–3 days; major depressive episodes as defined for major depressive disorder.

Hypomanic Episodes with Insufficient Sym.title: Hypomanic Episodes with Insufficient Symptoms and Major Depressive Episodes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual has experienced one or more major depressive episodes during their lifetime.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There has been at least one episode of hypomania that does not meet the full symptomatic criteria for a hypomanic episode.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The hypomanic and major depressive episodes do not overlap in time.

Hypomanic Episodes with Insufficient Sym.timeFrame: Lifetime history of major depressive episodes and at least one episode of hypomania with insufficient symptoms.

Hypomanic Episode without Prior Major De.title: Hypomanic Episode without Prior Major Depressive Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 4 consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy and activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms have persisted (four if the mood is only irritable), represent a noticeable change from usual behavior, and have been present to a significant degree: (a) Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity; (b) Decreased need for sleep; (c) More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking; (d) Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing; (e) Distractibility; (f) Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation; (g) Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharacteristic of the individual when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance in mood and the change in functioning are observable by others.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. If there are psychotic features, the episode is, by definition, manic.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a prior major depressive episode or manic episode.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Short-Duration Cyclothymia.title: Short-Duration Cyclothymia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Multiple periods with hypomanic symptoms and periods with depressive symptoms that do not meet criteria for a hypomanic episode or a major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The above symptoms have been present for more days than not.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The duration of the disturbance is less than 24 months in adults and less than 12 months in children and adolescents.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive, manic, or mixed episode have never been met.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The symptoms are not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Short-Duration Cyclothymia.timeFrame: Less than 24 months in adults; less than 12 months in children or adolescents, with symptoms present for more days than not.

With Anxious Distress.title: With Anxious Distress (Specifier for Bipolar and Related Disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The current or most recent episode of mood disturbance is accompanied by at least two of the following symptoms of anxiety during the majority of days:
subcriteria: 1. Feeling keyed up or tense.
2. Feeling unusually restless.
3. Difficulty concentrating because of worry.
4. Fear that something awful may happen.
5. Feeling that the individual might lose control of themselves.

With Anxious Distress.timeFrame: During the majority of days of the current or most recent episode.

With Mixed Features.title: With Mixed Features (Specifier for Bipolar and Related Disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: During a manic, hypomanic, or depressive episode, symptoms of the opposite mood pole are also present.
subcriteria: 1. For manic or hypomanic episodes, at least three symptoms of depression are present during the majority of days of the current or most recent episode.
2. For depressive episodes, at least three symptoms of mania/hypomania are present during the majority of days of the current or most recent episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mixed symptoms are observable by others and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mixed symptoms do not meet full criteria for a manic, hypomanic, or depressive episode.

With Mixed Features.timeFrame: During the majority of days of the current or most recent episode.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Dysphoria.title: Dysphoria

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A state of unease or generalized dissatisfaction, often characterized by sadness or irritability.

associatedFeatures: May include feelings of sadness, irritability, or restlessness

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The impact of a disorder on an individual's ability to function in social, occupational, or other important areas of life.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The impact of bipolar symptoms on an individual's ability to function in social, occupational, or other important areas, which may worsen outcomes or interfere with medical treatment.

Manic Episode, With Mixed Features.title: Manic Episode, With Mixed Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria are met both for a manic episode and for at least three symptoms of a major depressive episode (excluding symptoms that are clearly attributable to the manic episode), nearly every day during the majority of days of the current or most recent episode of mania.
subcriteria: 1. Full criteria for a manic episode are met.

2. At least three of the following depressive symptoms are present and observable by others: depressed mood, diminished interest or pleasure, psychomotor retardation, fatigue or loss of energy, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, recurrent thoughts of death or suicide.
3. The mixed symptoms are observable by others and represent a change from usual behavior.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or other treatment).

Manic Episode, With Mixed Features.timeFrame: During the majority of days of the current or most recent episode of mania.
associatedFeatures: Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning
differentialDiagnosis: Bipolar I Disorder, Manic Episode without Mixed Features
Major Depressive Episode with Mixed Features

Depressive Episode, With Mixed Features.title: Depressive Episode, With Mixed Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria are met for a major depressive episode.
subcriteria: 1. Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
2. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
3. The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: At least three of the following manic/hypomanic symptoms are present during the majority of days of the current or most recent episode of depression and are observable by others:
subcriteria: 1. Elevated, expansive mood
2. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing
5. Increase in energy or goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually)
6. Increased or excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences
7. Decreased need for sleep

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mixed symptoms are observable by others and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The mixed symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or other treatment).

associatedFeatures: Increased risk for developing bipolar disorder
Higher rates of comorbid anxiety and substance use disorders
Greater likelihood of suicidal ideation and behavior

Melancholic Features.title: Melancholic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: One of the following is present during the most severe period of the current episode:
subcriteria: 1. Loss of pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
2. Lack of reactivity to usually pleasurable stimuli (does not feel much better, even temporarily, when something good happens).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Three (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Distinct quality of depressed mood (profound despondency, despair, or moroseness, or empty mood).
2. Depression regularly worse in the morning.
3. Early-morning awakening (at least 2 hours before usual time of awakening).
4. Marked psychomotor agitation or retardation.
5. Significant anorexia or weight loss.
6. Excessive or inappropriate guilt.

differentialDiagnosis: Mood Disorders due to another medical condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Mood reactivity (i.e., mood brightens in response to actual or potential positive events) is present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: At least two of the following features are present:
subcriteria: 1. Significant weight gain or increase in appetite.
2. Hypersomnia.
3. Leaden paralysis (i.e., heavy, leaden feelings in arms or legs).
4. A long-standing pattern of interpersonal rejection sensitivity (not limited to episodes of mood disturbance) that results in significant social or occupational impairment.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Criteria are not met for 'with melancholic features' or 'with catatonic features' specifiers.

Mood Reactivity.title: Mood Reactivity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The capacity for mood to brighten in response to actual or potential positive events.
subcriteria: 1. Mood improves when receiving compliments.
2. Mood brightens during visits from loved ones or other positive occurrences.

associatedFeatures: Often observed in atypical depressive episodes.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder, with melancholic features

Leaden Paralysis.title: Leaden Paralysis

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A sensation of heaviness or a weighted-down feeling, usually in the arms or legs.
subcriteria: 1. The sensation often lasts for hours each day.

associatedFeatures: Frequently reported in individuals with depressive episodes, particularly with atypical features.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder without atypical features
comorbidity: Major Depressive Disorder, with atypical features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A long-standing pattern of heightened sensitivity to perceived interpersonal rejection.
subcriteria: 1. The individual experiences intense emotional responses to perceived or actual rejection.
2. The sensitivity is present both during and outside of mood episodes.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The pattern leads to significant social or occupational impairment.

Mood-Congruent Psychotic Features.title: Mood-Congruent Psychotic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of psychotic symptoms (delusions or hallucinations) during a mood episode.
subcriteria: 1. The content of the psychotic symptoms is consistent with the typical themes of the mood episode (e.g., grandiosity or invulnerability during mania; guilt, worthlessness, or deserved punishment during depression).

associatedFeatures: Themes of psychosis align with mood episode (e.g., grandiosity, guilt, deserved punishment)

Peripartum Onset.title: Peripartum Onset Specifier

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The onset of mood symptoms occurs during pregnancy or within four weeks following delivery in the context of a mood episode (major depressive, manic, or hypomanic) associated with bipolar I or II disorder.

Peripartum Onset.timeFrame: During pregnancy or within four weeks postpartum
associatedFeatures: May be associated with severe anxiety, panic attacks, or psychotic features
differentialDiagnosis: Major depressive disorder without peripartum onset

Seasonal Pattern.title: Seasonal Pattern (Specifier for Mood Disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There has been a regular temporal relationship between the onset of mood episodes (mania, hypomania, or depression) and a particular time of year.
subcriteria: 1. Episodes of depression or mania recur at a specific time of year (most commonly in winter).
2. Full remissions or a change to mania or hypomania also occur at a characteristic time of year.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: This pattern has been present for at least the last two years, with no nonseasonal episodes of the mood disturbance occurring during this period.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The seasonal episodes substantially outnumber any nonseasonal episodes that may have occurred over the individual's lifetime.

differentialDiagnosis: Mood disorder due to another medical condition

psychosocial stressors.title: Psychosocial Stressors

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of external social or environmental factors that cause psychological stress.
subcriteria: 1. Examples include, but are not limited to, recurrent unemployment (e.g., being unemployed every winter), relationship difficulties, or exposure to community violence.

associatedFeatures: May contribute to the onset, exacerbation, or maintenance of mental disorders.
Can impact coping abilities and overall functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: No significant signs or symptoms of the disturbance are present.
subcriteria: 1. The absence of clinically significant symptoms related to the disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The period of remission has lasted for at least 2 months.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period following a manic, hypomanic, or major depressive episode during which:
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms of the previous episode are present but do not meet full criteria for the episode, OR
2. There is a period lasting less than 2 months without significant symptoms following the end of the episode.

seasonal pattern.title: Seasonal Pattern (Specifier for Mood Disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There has been a regular temporal relationship between the onset of major depressive episodes (or manic or hypomanic episodes) and a particular time of the year (e.g., depression begins in fall or winter and remits in spring).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Full remissions (or a change from depression to mania or hypomania) also occur at a characteristic time of the year (e.g., depression remits in spring).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: In the last 2 years, the pattern has occurred without nonseasonal episodes of the mood disturbance.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Seasonal episodes substantially outnumber any nonseasonal episodes that may have occurred over the individual's lifetime.

differentialDiagnosis: Mood disorder due to another medical condition

bipolar I disorder.title: Bipolar I Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria have been met for at least one manic episode.
subcriteria: 1. A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

2. During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior (four if the mood is only irritable): inflated self-esteem or grandiosity; decreased need for sleep; more talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking; flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing; distractibility; increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation; excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The occurrence of the manic and major depressive episode(s) is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

bipolar I disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 week (for manic episode), or any duration if hospitalization is necessary.

bipolar II disorder.title: Bipolar II Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria have been met for at least one hypomanic episode and at least one major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The occurrence of the hypomanic episode(s) and major depressive episode(s) is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms of depression or the unpredictability caused by frequent alternation between periods of depression and hypomania causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

bipolar II disorder.timeFrame: Major depressive episode: at least two weeks; hypomanic episode: at least four consecutive days.

major depressive disorder, recurrent.title: Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day.
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The occurrence of the major depressive episodes is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

major depressive disorder, recurrent.timeFrame: At least two weeks per episode, with episodes separated by at least 2 months without significant symptoms.
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

manic episode.title: Manic Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep)
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments)

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization to prevent harm to self or others, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or other treatment) or to another medical condition.

manic episode.timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Episode with Mixed Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 4 consecutive days and present most of the day, nearly every day.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy and activity, three (or more) of the following symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) have persisted, represent a noticeable change from usual behavior, and have been present to a significant degree:
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility (i.e., attention too easily drawn to unimportant or irrelevant external stimuli), as reported or observed.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation.
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is associated with an unequivocal change in functioning that is uncharacteristic of the individual when not symptomatic.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance in mood and the change in functioning are observable by others.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The episode is not severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. If there are psychotic features, the episode is, by definition, manic.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others, not merely subjective feelings of restlessness or being slowed down).
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Severity is determined by the degree of symptom intensity, the number of manic symptoms present, and the level of functional disability experienced during the episode.
subcriteria: 1. Mild: Minimum number of symptoms and minor functional impairment.
2. Moderate: Intermediate number of symptoms and moderate functional impairment.
3. Severe: Nearly all symptoms present and marked impairment in social or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Severity is determined by the degree of symptom intensity, the number of depressive symptoms present, and the level of functional disability experienced during a major depressive episode.
subcriteria: 1. Mild: Few, if any, symptoms in excess of those required to make the diagnosis are present, and symptoms result in only minor functional impairment.
2. Moderate: The number of symptoms, intensity of symptoms, and/or functional impairment are between those specified for 'mild' and 'severe.'
3. Severe: Most symptoms are present and are markedly distressing and unmanageable, with significant interference in social and occupational functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Minimum symptom criteria are met for a manic episode.

moderate (manic episode).title: Manic Episode, Moderate Severity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased goal-directed activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week and present most of the day, nearly every day (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, very significant increase in activity or impairment in judgment is present.

moderate (manic episode).timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with mixed features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Almost continual supervision is required to prevent physical harm to self or others during a manic episode.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Few, if any, symptoms in excess of those required to meet diagnostic criteria are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms are distressing but manageable and result in minor impairment in social or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The number, intensity, and/or functional impairment of symptoms are between those specified for mild and severe.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The number of symptoms is substantially in excess of those required for diagnosis, the intensity is seriously distressing and unmanageable, and symptoms markedly interfere with social and occupational functioning.

Depressive Disorders.title: Depressive Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of sad, empty, or irritable mood, accompanied by somatic and cognitive changes that significantly affect the individual’s capacity to function.

associatedFeatures: Diminished ability to think or concentrate

Major Depressive Disorder.title: Major Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day, as indicated by either subjective report or observation made by others.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day (observable by others, not merely subjective feelings of restlessness or being slowed down).
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Persistent Depressive Disorder.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Poor appetite or overeating
2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
3. Low energy or fatigue
4. Low self-esteem
5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
6. Feelings of hopelessness

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During the 2-year period of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symptoms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Persistent Depressive Disorder.timeFrame: At least 2 years (1 year for children and adolescents)
specifiers: with intermittent major depressive episodes, with current episode
with intermittent major depressive episodes, without current episode
associatedFeatures: Generalized loss of interest or pleasure
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Dysthymia.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Poor appetite or overeating
2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
3. Low energy or fatigue
4. Low self-esteem
5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
6. Feelings of hopelessness

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During the 2-year period of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symptoms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Dysthymia.timeFrame: At least 2 years (1 year for children and adolescents)
specifiers: with intermittent major depressive episodes, with current episode
with intermittent major depressive episodes, without current episode
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive disorder due to another medical condition

Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder.title: Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: In the majority of menstrual cycles, at least five symptoms must be present in the final week before the onset of menses, start to improve within a few days after the onset of menses, and become minimal or absent in the week postmenses.
subcriteria: 1. Marked affective lability (e.g., mood swings; feeling suddenly sad or tearful, or increased sensitivity to rejection).
2. Marked irritability or anger or increased interpersonal conflicts.
3. Marked depressed mood, feelings of hopelessness, or self-deprecating thoughts.
4. Marked anxiety, tension, and/or feelings of being keyed up or on edge.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: One (or more) of the following symptoms must additionally be present, to reach a total of five symptoms when combined with symptoms from Criterion A:
subcriteria: 1. Decreased interest in usual activities (e.g., work, school, friends, hobbies).
2. Subjective difficulty in concentration.
3. Lethargy, easy fatigability, or marked lack of energy.
4. Marked change in appetite; overeating; or specific food cravings.
5. Hypersomnia or insomnia.
6. A sense of being overwhelmed or out of control.
7. Physical symptoms such as breast tenderness or swelling, joint or muscle pain, a sensation of 'bloating,' or weight gain.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are associated with clinically significant distress or interference with work, school, usual social activities, or relationships with others.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not merely an exacerbation of the symptoms of another disorder, such as major depressive disorder, panic disorder, persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia), or a personality disorder.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Criterion A should be confirmed by prospective daily ratings during at least two symptomatic cycles.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism).

Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder.timeFrame: In the majority of menstrual cycles, symptoms occur in the final week before menses, improve within a few days after onset, and are minimal or absent in the week postmenses.
associatedFeatures: Feelings of being overwhelmed or out of control
Physical symptoms such as breast tenderness, bloating, or weight gain
Marked changes in appetite or sleep

Substance/Medication-Induced Depressive.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both (1) and (2):
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the symptoms in Criterion A.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a depressive disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent depressive disorder could include: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence suggesting the existence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced depressive disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Substance/Medication-Induced Depressive.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or within 1 month of substance intoxication or withdrawal.
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medic.title: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, in which the stressor is a serious medical condition).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Other Specified Depressive Disorder.title: Other Specified Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressive symptoms that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning predominate.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms do not meet the full criteria for any of the disorders in the depressive disorders diagnostic class.

specifiers: with depressive episode with insufficient symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms characteristic of a depressive disorder that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning predominate.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The full criteria are not met for any of the specific depressive disorders.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses not to specify the reason that the criteria are not met for a specific depressive disorder, and this category is often used in emergency settings.

Irritability.title: Irritability

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A tendency to respond to events with anger, frustration, or outbursts.

associatedFeatures: Often observed in children and adolescents with depressive disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Episodes of intense verbal or behavioral expressions of anger, such as rages or aggression, that are disproportionate to the situation and developmentally inappropriate.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period of mourning and emotional response following a significant loss, such as the death of a loved one.

Unipolar Depressive Disorders.title: Unipolar Depressive Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more major depressive episodes.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure in nearly all activities.
2. Symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Unipolar Depressive Disorders.timeFrame: At least two weeks (for a major depressive episode)
associatedFeatures: Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide

Pediatric Bipolar Disorder.title: Pediatric Bipolar Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy, lasting at least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary), and present most of the day, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep.
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Distractibility.
6. Increase in goal-directed activity or psychomotor agitation.
7. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the period of mood disturbance and increased energy or activity, three (or more) of the above symptoms (four if the mood is only irritable) are present to a significant degree and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The mood disturbance is sufficiently severe to cause marked impairment in social or academic functioning or to necessitate hospitalization, or there are psychotic features.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Pediatric Bipolar Disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary)

Face-emotion labeling deficits.title: Face-Emotion Labeling Deficits

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent difficulties in accurately recognizing and identifying emotions expressed on human faces.
subcriteria: 1. Misinterpretation or failure to identify basic emotional expressions (e.g., happiness, sadness, anger, fear) in others.
2. Deficits are present across a variety of social contexts and are not attributable to sensory or intellectual impairment.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The deficits cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The difficulties are not better explained by visual impairment, intellectual disability, or another neurodevelopmental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Difficulty forming or maintaining interpersonal relationships

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Marked difficulty in regulating thoughts, emotions, or behaviors, particularly in the presence of distractions or conflicting information.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The process of directing and focusing attention, particularly in response to emotional stimuli.

Oppositional Defiant Disorder.title: Oppositional Defiant Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior, or vindictiveness lasting at least 6 months as evidenced by at least four symptoms from any of the following categories, and exhibited during interaction with at least one individual who is not a sibling.
subcriteria: 1. Often loses temper.
2. Is often touchy or easily annoyed.
3. Is often angry and resentful.
4. Often argues with authority figures or, for children and adolescents, with adults.
5. Often actively defies or refuses to comply with requests from authority figures or with rules.
6. Often deliberately annoys others.
7. Often blames others for his or her mistakes or misbehavior.
8. Has been spiteful or vindictive at least twice within the past 6 months.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance in behavior is associated with distress in the individual or others in his or her immediate social context (e.g., family, peer group, work colleagues), or it impacts negatively on social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The behaviors do not occur exclusively during the course of a psychotic, substance use, depressive, or bipolar disorder. Also, the criteria are not met for disruptive mood dysregulation disorder.

specifiers: Mild: Symptoms are confined to only one setting (e.g., at home, at school, at work, with peers).
Moderate: Some symptoms are present in at least two settings.
Severe: Some symptoms are present in three or more settings.
associatedFeatures: Increased risk for problems in emotional regulation.
May have difficulties in peer relationships.
May be associated with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

Outbursts.title: Outbursts

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Sudden, intense displays of anger or emotion that are disproportionate to the situation.

associatedFeatures: Episodes may be verbal or behavioral.
Often occur in response to minor provocations.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A group of mental disorders characterized by excessive fear, anxiety, or related behavioral disturbances.

Autism Spectrum Disorder.title: Autism Spectrum Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts, as manifested by all of the following, currently or by history:
subcriteria: 1. Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity.
2. Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction.
3. Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by at least two of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech.
2. Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal or nonverbal behavior.
3. Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus.
4. Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment.

criteria.label: C
