criteria.text: Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period (but may not become fully manifest until social demands exceed limited capacities, or may be masked by learned strategies in later life).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of current functioning.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder) or global developmental delay.

Autism Spectrum Disorder.timeFrame: Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period.
specifiers: with or without accompanying intellectual impairment
with or without accompanying language impairment
associated with a known medical or genetic condition or environmental factor

Intermittent Explosive Disorder.title: Intermittent Explosive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent behavioral outbursts representing a failure to control aggressive impulses as manifested by either of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Verbal aggression (e.g., temper tantrums, tirades, verbal arguments or fights) or physical aggression toward property, animals, or other individuals, occurring twice weekly, on average, for a period of 3 months. The physical aggression does not result in damage or destruction of property and does not result in physical injury to animals or other individuals.
2. Three behavioral outbursts involving damage or destruction of property and/or physical assault involving physical injury against animals or other individuals occurring within a 12-month period.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The magnitude of aggressiveness expressed during the recurrent outbursts is grossly out of proportion to the provocation or to any precipitating psychosocial stressors.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The recurrent aggressive outbursts are not premeditated (i.e., they are impulsive and/or anger-based) and are not committed to achieve some tangible objective (e.g., money, power, intimidation).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The recurrent aggressive outbursts cause either marked distress in the individual or impairment in occupational or interpersonal functioning, or are associated with financial or legal consequences.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Chronological age is at least 6 years (or equivalent developmental level).

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The recurrent aggressive outbursts are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, a psychotic disorder, antisocial personality disorder, borderline personality disorder), and are not attributable to another medical condition or to the physiological effects of a substance.

Intermittent Explosive Disorder.timeFrame: Verbal or non-damaging physical aggression: at least twice weekly for 3 months; damaging outbursts: three times in 12 months.
associatedFeatures: Feelings of remorse, regret, or embarrassment after outbursts

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive feeling of having no value or being unimportant.

Excessive or inappropriate guilt.title: Excessive or Inappropriate Guilt

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Feelings of guilt that are disproportionate or not justified by the situation.
subcriteria: 1. Guilt is excessive in relation to actual events.
2. Guilt may reach delusional intensity, not corresponding to reality.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by feelings of worthlessness.
Often observed in mood disorders such as Major Depressive Disorder.

Functional consequences.title: Functional Consequences

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The disorder results in significant impairment in the individual's ability to function in daily life, including areas such as work, relationships, or self-care.

associatedFeatures: Impairment may manifest as difficulties maintaining employment, academic performance, interpersonal relationships, or personal care.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The process of distinguishing a particular disease or disorder from other conditions that present with similar clinical features or symptoms.

Episodic illness.title: Episodic Illness

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There are clearly defined periods during which symptoms are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Periods of symptoms are separated by intervals of normal functioning.

associatedFeatures: Onset and remission of symptoms may be abrupt or gradual.
Duration and frequency of episodes may vary depending on the specific illness.
differentialDiagnosis: Recurrent illness (symptoms recur but may not have full remission between episodes)

Persistent mood disruption.title: Persistent Mood Disruption

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A continuous disturbance in mood, such as irritability or sadness, is present.
subcriteria: 1. The mood disturbance is observable by others (e.g., parents, teachers, peers).
2. The mood disturbance is present most of the day, nearly every day.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The mood disturbance persists for an extended period.

Persistent mood disruption.timeFrame: At least several weeks or longer

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A level of emotional suffering that is severe enough to interfere with social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A reduction in the ability to perform normally in social, work, or other significant life areas due to symptoms.

Self-esteem.title: Self-Esteem

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An individual's overall sense of self-worth or personal value.

associatedFeatures: May influence emotional well-being and interpersonal functioning

Suicidal ideation.title: Suicidal Ideation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of thoughts about wanting to die, wishing not to wake up, or considering suicide.
subcriteria: 1. Passive suicidal ideation (e.g., wishing to be dead or not wake up).
2. Active suicidal ideation (e.g., considering or planning suicide).

associatedFeatures: May occur with feelings of hopelessness or worthlessness
May be accompanied by depressive symptoms

Anxious distress.title: Major Depressive or Bipolar Disorder with Anxious Distress

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of at least two of the following symptoms during the majority of days of a major depressive episode or bipolar disorder episode:
subcriteria: 1. Feeling keyed up or tense.
2. Feeling unusually restless.
3. Difficulty concentrating because of worry.
4. Fear that something awful may happen.
5. Feeling that the individual might lose control of themselves.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms of anxious distress are associated with a higher risk of suicide, longer duration of illness, and greater likelihood of treatment nonresponse.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A significant increase or decrease in appetite, which may result in weight gain or loss.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent problems with sleep, as indicated by one or more of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Difficulty falling asleep.
2. Difficulty staying asleep.
3. Waking too early.
4. Sleeping excessively.

Decreased energy.title: Decreased Energy

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A persistent feeling of tiredness or fatigue, even without physical exertion.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by reduced motivation or diminished ability to initiate activities.

Guilt.title: Guilt

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Excessive or inappropriate feelings of responsibility or remorse for real or imagined faults or mistakes.

associatedFeatures: May be present in mood disorders such as Major Depressive Disorder
Can contribute to feelings of worthlessness

Delusional guilt.title: Delusional Guilt

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of a false and fixed belief that the individual is responsible for events or situations that are not actually their fault.
subcriteria: 1. The belief is held with conviction despite clear evidence to the contrary.
2. The belief is of an exaggerated or unrealistic nature.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The delusional belief is not better explained by cultural or religious beliefs.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The delusion causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Somatic complaints.title: Somatic Complaints

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of physical symptoms, such as aches and pains, that are emphasized by the individual.
subcriteria: 1. Physical symptoms are not fully explained by a general medical condition.
2. Physical symptoms may be presented instead of, or in addition to, emotional symptoms of depression.

associatedFeatures: Individuals with depression may report somatic complaints rather than emotional symptoms.

Impaired concentration.title: Impaired Concentration

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A reduced ability to think clearly, focus, or make decisions.
subcriteria: 1. Often experienced as distractibility.
2. May present as memory difficulties.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in mood, anxiety, and neurocognitive disorders.

Pseudodementia.title: Pseudodementia (Depression-Related Cognitive Impairment)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of significant cognitive impairment (e.g., memory loss, attention difficulties, executive dysfunction) that is clinically evident and interferes with social or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Cognitive impairment occurs in the context of a major depressive episode.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Cognitive symptoms are not better explained by a neurodegenerative disorder (e.g., Alzheimer's disease) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Cognitive impairment improves or resolves with effective treatment of depression.

Pseudodementia.timeFrame: During the course of a major depressive episode
associatedFeatures: Prominent depressive symptoms such as low mood, anhedonia, and fatigue
Cognitive testing may reveal inconsistent effort or performance

Suicide attempt.title: Suicide Attempt

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An act of self-inflicted harm is carried out.
subcriteria: 1. The act is performed with at least some intent to end one's own life.

associatedFeatures: May be associated with feelings of hopelessness, worthlessness, or severe psychological distress.
Often occurs in the context of mood, psychotic, or substance use disorders.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of depressive symptoms not related to physical or bodily (vegetative) functions.
subcriteria: 1. Dysphoria (depressed mood)
2. Anhedonia (markedly diminished interest or pleasure)
3. Excessive or inappropriate guilt
4. Feelings of worthlessness
5. Impaired concentration
6. Indecisiveness
7. Recurrent thoughts of death or suicidal ideation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Loss of interest or pleasure in activities that are usually found enjoyable.
2. Decreased ability to experience pleasure from positive stimuli or a degradation in the recollection of previously experienced pleasure.

Melancholia.title: Major Depressive Disorder, With Melancholic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A severe depressive episode characterized by the following:
subcriteria: 1. Profound sadness or depressed mood that is distinct and pervasive.
2. Marked lack of reactivity to usually pleasurable stimuli (i.e., does not feel better, even temporarily, when something good happens).

3. At least three of the following: a) distinct quality of depressed mood, b) depression regularly worse in the morning, c) early-morning awakening (at least 2 hours before usual time), d) marked psychomotor agitation or retardation, e) significant anorexia or weight loss, f) excessive or inappropriate guilt.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Melancholia.timeFrame: During the most severe period of the current episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a return of depressive symptoms following a period of remission.

Chronic depressive illness.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Poor appetite or overeating
2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
3. Low energy or fatigue
4. Low self-esteem
5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
6. Feelings of hopelessness

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During the 2-year period of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symptoms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Chronic depressive illness.timeFrame: At least 2 years (1 year for children and adolescents)
specifiers: with intermittent major depressive episodes, with current episode
with intermittent major depressive episodes, without current episode

Mixed features specifier.title: Mixed Features Specifier

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The current or most recent episode of major depressive disorder is characterized by the presence of at least three manic/hypomanic symptoms during the majority of days of the depressive episode.
subcriteria: 1. Elevated, expansive mood.
2. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
5. Increase in energy or goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually).
6. Increased or excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences.
7. Decreased need for sleep.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms are observable by others and represent a noticeable change from usual behavior.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Mixed features specifier.timeFrame: During the majority of days of the current or most recent episode of depression.
associatedFeatures: Increased risk for future bipolar disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive tendency toward negative emotional states.
subcriteria: 1. Frequent experiences of anxiety.
2. Frequent experiences of depression.
3. Frequent experiences of irritability.

Heritability.title: Heritability

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a measurable proportion of variation in a trait within a population that can be attributed to genetic factors.

associatedFeatures: Heritability estimates may vary depending on the trait and population studied.
Commonly referenced in the context of psychiatric and medical conditions, such as premenstrual symptoms.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Factors that influence the progression or outcome of a disorder, such as comorbid medical or psychiatric conditions.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one or more additional mental disorders occurring concurrently with a primary disorder.

Somatic symptoms.title: Somatic Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Physical symptoms, such as pain or fatigue, are present and may be the main complaint.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms are not fully explained by a general medical condition.
2. Symptoms may be prominent in depressive episodes, especially in some cultures.

associatedFeatures: Somatic symptoms may include pain, fatigue, or other bodily complaints.
These symptoms can be the primary reason for seeking medical attention in depressive disorders.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Excessive eating or increased appetite.

Personality disorders.title: Personality Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Enduring pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture.
subcriteria: 1. Manifested in two (or more) of the following areas: cognition, affectivity, interpersonal functioning, or impulse control.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is inflexible and pervasive across a broad range of personal and social situations.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The enduring pattern leads to clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The pattern is stable and of long duration, and its onset can be traced back at least to adolescence or early adulthood.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is not better explained as a manifestation or consequence of another mental disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Personality disorders.timeFrame: Onset can be traced back at least to adolescence or early adulthood
associatedFeatures: Can complicate the course of depression

Substance use disorders.title: Substance Use Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A problematic pattern of use of alcohol or other substances leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by at least two of the following, occurring within a 12-month period:
subcriteria: 1. The substance is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended.
2. There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control substance use.
3. A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain, use, or recover from the substance’s effects.
4. Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use the substance.
5. Recurrent substance use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home.
6. Continued substance use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of the substance.
7. Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of substance use.
8. Recurrent substance use in situations in which it is physically hazardous.
9. Substance use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by the substance.

10. Tolerance, as defined by either: (a) a need for markedly increased amounts of the substance to achieve intoxication or desired effect, or (b) a markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of the substance.
11. Withdrawal, as manifested by either: (a) the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for the substance, or (b) the substance is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms.

associatedFeatures: May increase the risk and complicate the course of depression

Adverse childhood experiences.title: Adverse Childhood Experiences

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Exposure to one or more stressful or traumatic events during childhood, such as abuse or neglect.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The individual demonstrates an increased risk for developing depressive disorders or related psychopathology.

associatedFeatures: May include emotional, physical, or sexual abuse; emotional or physical neglect; household dysfunction.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The proportion of a population found to have a condition at a specific time.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The proportion of individuals in a population who have a specific disorder at a given time.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The rate of new cases of a disorder occurring in a specified period.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a likelihood that the individual will attempt or die by suicide.
subcriteria: 1. Risk is elevated in the presence of major depressive disorder.
2. Risk is often increased in mood and psychotic disorders.

Obsessive rumination.title: Obsessive Rumination

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Repetitive and persistent thinking about distressing topics.
subcriteria: 1. The thoughts are intrusive and difficult to control.
2. The content of the rumination is typically negative or distressing.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The rumination is associated with significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by feelings of hopelessness or helplessness

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A feeling of worry, nervousness, or unease that is difficult to control.

Phobia.title: Specific Phobia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Marked fear or anxiety about a specific object or situation (e.g., flying, heights, animals, receiving an injection, seeing blood).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The phobic object or situation almost always provokes immediate fear or anxiety.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The phobic object or situation is actively avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The fear or anxiety is out of proportion to the actual danger posed by the specific object or situation and to the sociocultural context.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting for 6 months or more.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder, including fear, anxiety, and avoidance of situations associated with panic-like symptoms or other disabling symptoms (as in agoraphobia); objects or situations related to obsessions (as in obsessive-compulsive disorder); reminders of traumatic events (as in posttraumatic stress disorder); separation from home or attachment figures (as in separation anxiety disorder); or social situations (as in social anxiety disorder).

Phobia.timeFrame: Typically lasting for 6 months or more
associatedFeatures: Physiological symptoms such as sweating, palpitations, or trembling

Separation anxiety.title: Separation Anxiety Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Developmentally inappropriate and excessive fear or anxiety concerning separation from those to whom the individual is attached, as evidenced by at least three of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Recurrent excessive distress when anticipating or experiencing separation from home or from major attachment figures.
2. Persistent and excessive worry about losing major attachment figures or about possible harm to them.
3. Persistent and excessive worry about experiencing an untoward event that causes separation from a major attachment figure.
4. Persistent reluctance or refusal to go out, away from home, to school, to work, or elsewhere because of fear of separation.
5. Persistent and excessive fear of or reluctance about being alone or without major attachment figures.
6. Persistent reluctance or refusal to sleep away from home or to go to sleep without being near a major attachment figure.
7. Repeated nightmares involving the theme of separation.
8. Repeated complaints of physical symptoms when separation from major attachment figures occurs or is anticipated.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, lasting at least 4 weeks in children and adolescents and typically 6 months or more in adults.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, academic, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as refusing to leave home because of excessive resistance to change in autism spectrum disorder; delusions or hallucinations concerning separation in psychotic disorders; refusal to go outside without a trusted companion in agoraphobia; worries about ill health or other harm befalling significant others in generalized anxiety disorder; or concerns about having an illness in illness anxiety disorder.

Separation anxiety.timeFrame: At least 4 weeks in children and adolescents; typically 6 months or more in adults.
associatedFeatures: May be seen in children with depressive symptoms.
May present with school refusal, somatic complaints, or nightmares.

Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis hype.title: Hypothalamic-Pituitary-Adrenal Axis Hyperactivity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent increased activity in the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis, as evidenced by elevated levels of stress hormones (e.g., cortisol), not attributable to a medical condition or substance use.

associatedFeatures: Frequently observed in individuals with severe depressive episodes
May be associated with symptoms of anxiety, sleep disturbance, and impaired stress response

Neurotrophic factors.title: Neurotrophic Factors

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of proteins that support the growth and survival of neurons.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Genetic variants of neurotrophic factors are implicated in the pathophysiology of depression.

associatedFeatures: Altered neurotrophic factor expression may be associated with mood disorders, particularly depression.

Pro-inflammatory cytokines.title: Pro-inflammatory Cytokines

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of molecules involved in inflammation that may play a role in the development of depression.

associatedFeatures: May be elevated in individuals with depressive disorders
Linked to neurobiological changes associated with mood disturbances

Functional magnetic resonance imaging (f.title: Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI)
associatedFeatures: A brain imaging technique used to study functional abnormalities in neural systems related to emotion and reward in depression.

Symptom severity.title: Symptom Severity (Depressive Symptoms)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The intensity or degree of depressive symptoms is assessed to determine the impact on functioning and prognosis.

associatedFeatures: Symptom severity can influence recovery and overall prognosis.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The condition tends to occur more frequently among biological family members than in the general population, suggesting a genetic or hereditary component.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pattern of illness that does not respond well to treatment.

Somatic complaint.title: Somatic Complaint

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: One or more physical symptoms are reported by the individual, which may not be fully explained by a medical condition.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The somatic complaint may represent the primary manifestation of psychological distress, such as depression, particularly in certain cultural contexts.

associatedFeatures: Somatic complaints may include pain, fatigue, or gastrointestinal symptoms.
In some cultures, psychological distress is more likely to be expressed through physical symptoms rather than emotional or cognitive complaints.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A self-initiated behavior with the intent to end one's own life that results in death.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Death resulting from an act of self-inflicted harm with the intent to end one's own life.

Suicide Attempt.title: Suicide Attempt

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An act in which an individual engages in behavior with at least some intent to end their own life, but which does not result in death.

associatedFeatures: May be associated with psychiatric disorders such as major depressive disorder, bipolar disorder, or borderline personality disorder.
Often accompanied by feelings of hopelessness, worthlessness, or acute psychological distress.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A self-initiated behavior with the intent to end one's own life that results in death.

Borderline Personality Disorder.title: Borderline Personality Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive pattern of instability of interpersonal relationships, self-image, and affects, and marked impulsivity, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Frantic efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment.
2. A pattern of unstable and intense interpersonal relationships characterized by alternating between extremes of idealization and devaluation.
3. Identity disturbance: markedly and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self.
4. Impulsivity in at least two areas that are potentially self-damaging (e.g., spending, sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating).
5. Recurrent suicidal behavior, gestures, or threats, or self-mutilating behavior.
6. Affective instability due to a marked reactivity of mood (e.g., intense episodic dysphoria, irritability, or anxiety usually lasting a few hours and only rarely more than a few days).
7. Chronic feelings of emptiness.
8. Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty controlling anger (e.g., frequent displays of temper, constant anger, recurrent physical fights).
9. Transient, stress-related paranoid ideation or severe dissociative symptoms.

Borderline Personality Disorder.timeFrame: Beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts.
associatedFeatures: High risk for suicide attempts and self-mutilating behavior
differentialDiagnosis: Other Personality Disorders (e.g., Histrionic, Narcissistic, Antisocial)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a reduction in the ability to function normally due to symptoms of a disorder.

Catatonic.title: Catatonic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical picture is dominated by three (or more) of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Stupor (i.e., no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment)
2. Catalepsy (i.e., passive induction of a posture held against gravity)
3. Waxy flexibility (i.e., slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner)
4. Mutism (i.e., no, or very little, verbal response)
5. Negativism (i.e., opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli)
6. Posturing (i.e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity)
7. Mannerism (i.e., odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions)
8. Stereotypy (i.e., repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements)
9. Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
10. Grimacing
11. Echolalia (i.e., mimicking another's speech)
12. Echopraxia (i.e., mimicking another's movements)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., a manic episode).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: May include immobility, mutism, negativism, posturing, and echolalia or echopraxia

Mixed Episode.title: Mixed Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria are met both for a manic episode and for a major depressive episode (except for duration) nearly every day during at least a 1-week period.

associatedFeatures: Marked impairment in social or occupational functioning
differentialDiagnosis: Bipolar I Disorder, current episode manic
Bipolar I Disorder, current episode depressed

Mood Disorder Due to Another Medical Con.title: Mood Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by either a depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities, or by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, in which the stressor is a serious medical condition).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Symptoms may include sadness, irritability, loss of interest, or elevated mood depending on the type of mood disturbance.

Substance/Medication-Induced Depressive.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Depressive or Bipolar Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by either (1) depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities, or (2) an abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
2. Abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both (1) and (2):
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the mood symptoms.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a mood disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent mood disorder could include: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence suggesting the existence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced mood disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Symptoms may include feelings of worthlessness, hopelessness, or excessive guilt.
May present with psychomotor agitation or retardation.

Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood.title: Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor(s) occurring within 3 months of the onset of the stressor(s).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: These symptoms or behaviors are clinically significant, as evidenced by one or both of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Marked distress that is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor, taking into account the external context and the cultural factors that might influence symptom severity and presentation.
2. Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder and is not merely an exacerbation of a preexisting mental disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Once the stressor or its consequences have terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months.

Adjustment Disorder with Depressed Mood.timeFrame: Symptoms develop within 3 months of the onset of the stressor and do not persist for more than 6 months after the stressor or its consequences have ended.
specifiers: with mixed anxiety and depressed mood
with mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Sadness is a normal human emotion that, by itself, does not constitute a depressive disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Sadness may only be considered part of a depressive disorder if accompanied by sufficient severity, duration, and impairment.

Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymi.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years (at least 1 year for children and adolescents).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Poor appetite or overeating
2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
3. Low energy or fatigue
4. Low self-esteem
5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
6. Feelings of hopelessness

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During the 2-year period (1 year for children or adolescents) of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symptoms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymi.timeFrame: At least 2 years (1 year for children and adolescents)
specifiers: with intermittent major depressive episodes, with current episode
with intermittent major depressive episodes, without current episode
associatedFeatures: Generalized loss of interest or pleasure
Feelings of guilt or brooding about the past
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Dysthymic Disorder.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Poor appetite or overeating
2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
3. Low energy or fatigue
4. Low self-esteem
5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
6. Feelings of hopelessness

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During the 2-year period of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symptoms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Dysthymic Disorder.timeFrame: At least 2 years (1 year for children and adolescents)
specifiers: with intermittent major depressive episodes, with current episode
with intermittent major depressive episodes, without current episode

Schizoaffective Disorder.title: Schizoaffective Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An uninterrupted period of illness during which there is a major mood episode (major depressive or manic) concurrent with Criterion A of schizophrenia.
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Delusions or hallucinations for 2 or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode (depressive or manic) during the lifetime duration of the illness.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Symptoms that meet criteria for a major mood episode are present for the majority of the total duration of the active and residual portions of the illness.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Schizoaffective Disorder.timeFrame: Delusions or hallucinations must be present for 2 or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode.
specifiers: First episode, currently in acute episode
First episode, currently in partial remission
First episode, currently in full remission
Multiple episodes, currently in acute episode
Multiple episodes, currently in partial remission
Multiple episodes, currently in full remission
differentialDiagnosis: Bipolar I Disorder with psychotic features
Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Delusional Disorder.title: Delusional Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

associatedFeatures: Mood disturbances related to delusional content
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Onset of a disorder before age 21 years.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Onset of the disorder occurs at age 21 years or older.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent depressive symptoms have been present for at least two years.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: No episode of major depression has occurred during the past two years.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A major depressive episode is present, characterized by five (or more) of the following symptoms during the same 2-week period and representing a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day.
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The major depressive episode has persisted for at least a two-year duration and remains present.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: There has never been a manic or hypomanic episode.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Intermittent Major Depressive Episodes,.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder, Intermittent Major Depressive Episodes, With Current Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Currently meets full criteria for a major depressive episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Depressive symptoms have been present for at least two years.

associatedFeatures: Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions

Intermittent Major Depressive Episodes,.title: Intermittent Major Depressive Episodes, Without Current Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Full criteria for a major depressive episode are not currently met.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There has been at least one previous episode of major depression.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The individual has experienced at least two years of persistent depressive symptoms.

Intermittent Major Depressive Episodes,.timeFrame: At least two years of persistent depressive symptoms, with at least one prior major depressive episode.

Severity.title: Severity (Specifier)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Severity is determined by a quantitative assessment of the primary symptoms, including the number of symptoms present, their intensity, and the degree of functional disability they cause.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms are rated on a 5-point scale from 0 (not present) to 4 (present and severe).
2. Symptoms assessed may include delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, abnormal psychomotor behavior, and negative symptoms.

associatedFeatures: Severity ratings may guide treatment planning and prognosis.

Negative Affectivity.title: Negative Affectivity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A temperament characterized by frequent and intense experiences of negative emotions.

associatedFeatures: May include feelings such as anxiety, depression, guilt, shame, anger, and irritability.

Global Functioning.title: Global Functioning

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is an overall assessment of the individual's ability to function in daily life, including social, occupational, and psychological domains.

associatedFeatures: May be influenced by physical health, mental health symptoms, and environmental factors.
differentialDiagnosis: Specific mental disorders that may impact functioning (e.g., Major Depressive Disorder, Schizophrenia).
comorbidity: Any mental or physical disorder that may affect daily functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Irregularities in sleep patterns as measured by polysomnography.

Prefrontal Cortex.title: Prefrontal Cortex Dysfunction (as related to Depressive Disorders)
associatedFeatures: A region of the brain implicated in mood regulation and associated with depressive disorders.

Amygdala.title: Amygdala
associatedFeatures: A brain structure involved in emotion processing, often implicated in mood disorders.

Hippocampus.title: Hippocampus
associatedFeatures: A brain region involved in memory and emotion, implicated in depressive disorders.

Anterior Cingulate.title: Anterior Cingulate
associatedFeatures: A part of the brain involved in emotion regulation and implicated in mood disorders.

Psychotic Disorders.title: Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following symptoms indicating a disconnection from reality:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized thinking (speech)
4. Grossly disorganized or abnormal motor behavior (including catatonia)
5. Negative symptoms (e.g., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

associatedFeatures: Depressive symptoms may be present as associated features

Depressive or Bipolar and Related Disord.title: Depressive or Bipolar and Related Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities, or a distinct period of abnormally elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, delirium).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may fluctuate with the course of the medical condition

Personality Disorders.title: Personality Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: An enduring pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture.
subcriteria: 1. Manifested in two (or more) of the following areas: cognition, affectivity, interpersonal functioning, or impulse control.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is inflexible and pervasive across a broad range of personal and social situations.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The enduring pattern leads to clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The pattern is stable and of long duration, and its onset can be traced back at least to adolescence or early adulthood.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is not better explained as a manifestation or consequence of another mental disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The enduring pattern is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Personality Disorders.timeFrame: Onset can be traced back at least to adolescence or early adulthood; pattern is stable and of long duration.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Marked and rapid changes in mood.
subcriteria: 1. Mood swings.
2. Feeling suddenly sad or tearful.
3. Increased sensitivity to rejection.

Lethargy.title: Lethargy

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A state characterized by tiredness, lack of energy, or easy fatigability.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by decreased motivation or reduced activity.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A reduced desire or motivation to engage in usual activities.
subcriteria: 1. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
2. The reduction is evident in work, school, socializing, or hobbies.

Premenstrual Syndrome.title: Premenstrual Syndrome

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of physical and/or behavioral symptoms that occur during the premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms may include, but are not limited to, breast tenderness, bloating, headache, fatigue, irritability, or changes in sleep or appetite.
2. Symptoms do not require a minimum number or the presence of affective symptoms.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms are less severe than those seen in premenstrual dysphoric disorder and do not cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Symptoms remit shortly after the onset of menses.

Premenstrual Syndrome.timeFrame: Symptoms occur during the premenstrual phase of most menstrual cycles.
associatedFeatures: Physical discomfort such as bloating or breast tenderness

Dysmenorrhea.title: Dysmenorrhea

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent episodes of painful menstruation, with symptoms beginning at the onset of menses.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The pain is not better explained by mood or affective changes.

Dysmenorrhea.timeFrame: Symptoms occur with the onset of menses during each menstrual cycle.
associatedFeatures: May include lower abdominal cramping, back pain, and other somatic symptoms.

Prospective Daily Ratings.title: Prospective Daily Ratings

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A method of symptom assessment in which individuals record their symptoms daily over a period of time to confirm the presence and pattern of symptoms.
subcriteria: 1. Especially used in diagnosing premenstrual dysphoric disorder.

Prospective Daily Ratings.timeFrame: Daily over a period of time
associatedFeatures: Helps confirm the presence and pattern of symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a significant reduction in the ability to function socially, occupationally, or in other important areas of life due to symptoms of a mental disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Course modifiers are factors that can influence the development, severity, or progression of a disorder.
subcriteria: 1. Examples include the use of oral contraceptives in premenstrual dysphoric disorder.

Bipolar disorder.title: Bipolar I Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Criteria have been met for at least one manic episode. The manic episode may have been preceded by and may be followed by hypomanic or major depressive episodes.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The occurrence of the manic and major depressive episode(s) is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

Bipolar disorder.timeFrame: Manic episode: at least 1 week (or any duration if hospitalization is necessary); Major depressive episode: at least 2 weeks

Major depressive disorder.title: Major Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Five (or more) of the following symptoms have been present during the same 2-week period and represent a change from previous functioning; at least one of the symptoms is either (1) depressed mood or (2) loss of interest or pleasure.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood most of the day, nearly every day.
2. Markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day.
3. Significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, or decrease or increase in appetite nearly every day.
4. Insomnia or hypersomnia nearly every day.
5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation nearly every day.
6. Fatigue or loss of energy nearly every day.
7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt nearly every day.
8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, or indecisiveness, nearly every day.
9. Recurrent thoughts of death, recurrent suicidal ideation without a specific plan, or a suicide attempt or a specific plan for committing suicide.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The occurrence of the major depressive episode is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Persistent depressive disorder (dysthymi.title: Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthymia)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood for most of the day, for more days than not, as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence, while depressed, of two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Poor appetite or overeating
2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
3. Low energy or fatigue
4. Low self-esteem
5. Poor concentration or difficulty making decisions
6. Feelings of hopelessness

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: During the 2-year period of the disturbance, the individual has never been without the symptoms in Criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

specifiers: with intermittent major depressive episodes, with current episode
with intermittent major depressive episodes, without current episode

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder.title: Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: In the majority of menstrual cycles, at least five symptoms must be present in the final week before the onset of menses, start to improve within a few days after the onset of menses, and become minimal or absent in the week postmenses.
subcriteria: 1. Marked affective lability (e.g., mood swings; feeling suddenly sad or tearful, or increased sensitivity to rejection).
2. Marked irritability or anger or increased interpersonal conflicts.
3. Marked depressed mood, feelings of hopelessness, or self-deprecating thoughts.
4. Marked anxiety, tension, and/or feelings of being keyed up or on edge.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: One (or more) of the following symptoms must additionally be present, to reach a total of five symptoms when combined with symptoms from Criterion A:
subcriteria: 1. Decreased interest in usual activities (e.g., work, school, friends, hobbies).
2. Subjective difficulty in concentration.
3. Lethargy, easy fatigability, or marked lack of energy.
4. Marked change in appetite; overeating; or specific food cravings.
5. Hypersomnia or insomnia.
6. A sense of being overwhelmed or out of control.
7. Physical symptoms such as breast tenderness or swelling, joint or muscle pain, a sensation of 'bloating,' or weight gain.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are associated with clinically significant distress or interference with work, school, usual social activities, or relationships with others.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not merely an exacerbation of the symptoms of another disorder, such as major depressive disorder, panic disorder, persistent depressive disorder (dysthymia), or a personality disorder.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Criterion A should be confirmed by prospective daily ratings during at least two symptomatic cycles.

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, other treatment) or another medical condition (e.g., hyperthyroidism).

Premenstrual dysphoric disorder.timeFrame: In the majority of menstrual cycles, symptoms occur in the final week before menses, improve within a few days after onset of menses, and are minimal or absent in the week postmenses.
associatedFeatures: Feelings of being overwhelmed or out of control
Physical symptoms such as breast tenderness, bloating, or weight gain

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The development of a reversible, substance-specific syndrome due to the recent ingestion of a substance.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Clinically significant problematic behavioral or psychological changes (e.g., impaired judgment, mood changes) that are attributable to the effect of the substance on the central nervous system and develop during or shortly after use of the substance.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Cessation of (or reduction in) substance use that has been heavy and prolonged.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The development of a substance-specific syndrome due to cessation of (or reduction in) substance use.
subcriteria: 1. The syndrome causes clinically significant physical or psychological symptoms.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to another medical condition and are not better explained by another mental disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The process of recording symptoms on a daily basis moving forward in time, rather than relying on retrospective recall.

Retrospective symptoms.title: Retrospective Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms are reported based on the individual's recollection of past experiences, rather than being documented or observed in real time.

associatedFeatures: May be influenced by recall bias or inaccuracies in memory.

Premenstrual exacerbation.title: Premenstrual Exacerbation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a clear worsening of symptoms of an existing mental or medical disorder during the premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is no symptom-free interval following menses; symptoms persist outside the premenstrual phase.

Premenstrual exacerbation.timeFrame: During the premenstrual phase of the menstrual cycle, without a symptom-free interval post-menses.
associatedFeatures: May be observed in mood, anxiety, psychotic, or medical disorders.
Symptoms may include increased severity of pre-existing psychiatric or medical symptoms.
differentialDiagnosis: Primary psychiatric or medical disorder without cyclical exacerbation
comorbidity: Medical conditions affected by hormonal changes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A cause or contributing factor in the development of a disease or disorder.

Primary Depressive Disorder.title: Primary Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A depressive episode characterized by persistent depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure in most activities.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The depressive episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The depressive episode arises independently and is not better explained by another mental disorder.

differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Medication-Induced Depressive Disorder.title: Medication-Induced Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms develop during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is etiologically related to the effects of a medication.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a depressive disorder that is not substance/medication-induced.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Medication-Induced Depressive Disorder.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or soon after medication exposure.
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
comorbidity: Medical conditions for which the medication was prescribed

Substance Intoxication.title: Substance Intoxication

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A reversible, substance-specific syndrome due to recent ingestion of a substance.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The syndrome is associated with clinically significant behavioral or psychological changes (e.g., mood disturbances such as depression).

Substance Intoxication.timeFrame: During or shortly after substance use

Substance Withdrawal.title: Substance Withdrawal

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Cessation of (or reduction in) substance use that has been heavy and prolonged.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The development of a substance-specific withdrawal syndrome, as evidenced by a group of symptoms that occur following the abrupt discontinuation or decrease in intake of the substance.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms may include depressive symptoms and other substance-specific features.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The withdrawal syndrome causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Physical symptoms specific to the substance
differentialDiagnosis: Other mental disorders (e.g., depressive disorders, anxiety disorders)

Withdrawal Syndrome.title: Withdrawal Syndrome

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A set of symptoms develops after cessation or reduction in use of a substance to which the individual has become dependent.

associatedFeatures: Symptoms may include anxiety, irritability, fatigue, nausea, and other substance-specific signs.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A state of unease or generalized dissatisfaction is present.

Antisocial Behavior.title: Antisocial Behavior

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Actions that harm or lack consideration for the well-being of others.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in individuals with certain personality disorders, such as Antisocial Personality Disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of life events or environmental factors that may contribute to the onset or worsening of a mental disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressive symptoms are present during the course of the disorder.
subcriteria: 1. Symptoms do not meet full criteria for a major depressive episode.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Full criteria for a major depressive episode are met, except for exclusion of another mental disorder.

Depressive disorder due to another medic.title: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent period of depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities that predominates in the clinical picture.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., adjustment disorder, in which the stressor is a serious medical condition).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A physical health condition or disease is present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The medical condition may have physiological effects on mood or behavior.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The medical condition can be etiologically related to psychiatric symptoms.

Neuroanatomical correlates.title: Neuroanatomical Correlates
associatedFeatures: Brain structures or regions that are associated with the presence or development of a disorder, such as depression.

Cushing’s disease.title: Cushing’s Disease

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of a neuroendocrine disorder characterized by chronic exposure to excess cortisol, typically due to an adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-secreting pituitary adenoma.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Mood symptoms are present, which may include depressive or manic features.

differentialDiagnosis: Other causes of hypercortisolism (e.g., Cushing’s syndrome from adrenal tumors)

Hypothyroidism.title: Hypothyroidism

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Evidence of underactivity of the thyroid gland, as indicated by clinical assessment and/or laboratory findings.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The condition may be associated with depressive symptoms, such as low mood, fatigue, or cognitive impairment.

differentialDiagnosis: Other medical conditions causing fatigue or mood symptoms

Cerebrovascular accident (CVA).title: Cerebrovascular Accident (CVA)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Acute onset of neurological deficits due to interruption of blood supply to the brain (stroke).

associatedFeatures: May be associated with the acute onset of depression.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A progressive neurodegenerative disorder with a known genetic etiology (CAG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the HTT gene).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Characterized by motor, cognitive, and psychiatric disturbances, with depression often presenting early in the course.

Parkinson’s disease.title: Parkinson’s Disease

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of a progressive neurological disorder characterized by bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance may be associated with mood symptoms, such as depression, which can sometimes precede the onset of motor symptoms.

associatedFeatures: Depression may occur and can precede motor symptoms

Adjustment disorder.title: Adjustment Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The development of emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor(s) occurring within 3 months of the onset of the stressor(s).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: These symptoms or behaviors are clinically significant, as evidenced by one or both of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Marked distress that is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor, taking into account the external context and the cultural factors that might influence symptom severity and presentation.
2. Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder and is not merely an exacerbation of a preexisting mental disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Once the stressor or its consequences have terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than an additional 6 months.

Adjustment disorder.timeFrame: Symptoms develop within 3 months of the onset of the stressor and do not persist for more than 6 months after the stressor or its consequences have ended.
specifiers: With mixed anxiety and depressed mood
With mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct

Medication-induced depressive disorder.title: Medication-Induced Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms develop during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is etiologically related to the effects of a medication or substance.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a depressive disorder that is not substance/medication-induced.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Medication-induced depressive disorder.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or soon after substance/medication use and persist beyond the expected period of intoxication or withdrawal.
differentialDiagnosis: Depressive Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Feelings of nervousness, worry, or fear are present.
subcriteria: 1. These symptoms may occur regardless of the underlying cause.
2. Commonly observed in the context of depressive disorders.

Other specified depressive disorder.title: Other Specified Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressive symptoms that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning predominate.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The presentation does not meet the full criteria for any of the disorders in the depressive disorders diagnostic class.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses to communicate the specific reason that the presentation does not meet the criteria for any specific depressive disorder (e.g., recurrent brief depression, short-duration depressive episode, depressive episode with insufficient symptoms).

associatedFeatures: May include symptoms such as low mood, anhedonia, fatigue, or changes in sleep or appetite

Recurrent brief depression.title: Recurrent Brief Depression

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Recurrent episodes of depressed mood accompanied by at least four other depressive symptoms.
subcriteria: 1. Depressed mood.

2. At least four additional symptoms of depression (e.g., diminished interest or pleasure, significant weight change or appetite disturbance, insomnia or hypersomnia, psychomotor agitation or retardation, fatigue or loss of energy, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, diminished ability to think or concentrate, recurrent thoughts of death).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Each episode lasts for 2–13 days.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Episodes occur at least once per month for at least 12 consecutive months.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Criteria are not met for any other depressive or bipolar disorder.

Recurrent brief depression.timeFrame: Episodes last 2–13 days and occur at least once per month for at least 12 consecutive months.

Short-duration depressive episode.title: Short-duration Depressive Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period of depressed mood is present.
subcriteria: 1. The individual experiences a depressed mood.

2. At least four additional symptoms of major depressive episode are present (e.g., significant weight change, insomnia or hypersomnia, psychomotor agitation or retardation, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, diminished ability to think or concentrate, recurrent thoughts of death).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The episode lasts more than 4 days but less than 14 days.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The episode does not meet criteria for any other depressive or bipolar disorder.

Short-duration depressive episode.timeFrame: More than 4 days but less than 14 days

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressed mood is present for most of the day, nearly every day.
subcriteria: 1. Presence of at least one additional symptom of major depressive episode (e.g., diminished interest or pleasure, significant weight change, insomnia or hypersomnia, psychomotor agitation or retardation, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt, diminished ability to think or concentrate, recurrent thoughts of death).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The episode lasts at least 2 weeks.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The full criteria for a major depressive episode are not met.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The episode is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Depressive symptoms that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning predominate.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The presentation does not meet the full criteria for any specific depressive disorder.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses not to specify the reason that the criteria are not met for a specific depressive disorder, or there is insufficient information to make a more specific diagnosis.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Severity is determined by the number of depressive symptoms present and the degree of functional impairment.
subcriteria: 1. Mild: Two symptoms.
2. Moderate: Three symptoms.
3. Moderate-Severe: Four or five symptoms.
4. Severe: Four or five symptoms with motor agitation.

Manic/hypomanic symptoms.title: Manic/Hypomanic Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently increased activity or energy.
subcriteria: 1. Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity.
2. Decreased need for sleep (e.g., feels rested after only 3 hours of sleep).
3. More talkative than usual or pressure to keep talking.
4. Flight of ideas or subjective experience that thoughts are racing.
