5. Increase in goal-directed activity (either socially, at work or school, or sexually) or psychomotor agitation.
6. Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for painful consequences (e.g., engaging in unrestrained buying sprees, sexual indiscretions, or foolish business investments).

associatedFeatures: May include distractibility, increased sociability, and impulsivity.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The capacity for mood to brighten in response to actual or potential positive events.

Leaden paralysis.title: Leaden Paralysis

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A sensation of heaviness or being weighted down, usually in the arms or legs, present for at least an hour a day and often lasting for many hours.

Leaden paralysis.timeFrame: Present for at least an hour a day and often lasting for many hours.
associatedFeatures: May be associated with depressive episodes, particularly with atypical features.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with atypical features

Interpersonal rejection sensitivity.title: Interpersonal Rejection Sensitivity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A long-standing pattern of pathological sensitivity to perceived interpersonal rejection.
subcriteria: 1. The individual experiences intense emotional distress or preoccupation in response to perceived or actual interpersonal rejection.
2. The sensitivity is disproportionate to the actual situation or context.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The pattern of rejection sensitivity results in significant social or occupational impairment.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The pattern persists throughout most of adult life.

Interpersonal rejection sensitivity.timeFrame: Persisting throughout most of adult life

Postpartum psychotic features.title: Mood Episode With Postpartum Psychotic Features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual is experiencing a mood episode (major depressive, manic, or mixed) with onset during the postpartum period (within 4 weeks after childbirth).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the mood episode, psychotic symptoms such as delusions or hallucinations are present.
subcriteria: 1. Psychotic symptoms may include command hallucinations.
2. Delusions may involve the infant.

associatedFeatures: Command hallucinations related to the infant

Recurrent Major Depressive Disorder.title: Recurrent Major Depressive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of two or more major depressive episodes.
subcriteria: 1. Each episode meets criteria for Major Depressive Episode.
2. Episodes are separated by at least 2 consecutive months in which criteria are not met.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The occurrence of the major depressive episodes is not better explained by schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, schizophreniform disorder, delusional disorder, or other specified and unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode.

Recurrent Major Depressive Disorder.timeFrame: Episodes last at least two weeks, separated by periods of remission of at least two months.
associatedFeatures: Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
Diminished ability to think or concentrate
Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide

Bipolar Disorders.title: Bipolar Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more episodes of mania, hypomania, and/or major depression.

associatedFeatures: Changes in energy and activity levels

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period during which improvement after a previous episode is maintained, but some diagnostic criteria for the disorder are still met.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Some symptoms of a previous major depressive episode are still present, but the full criteria for the disorder are not met, or there is a period of less than 2 months without significant symptoms following an episode.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period following a previous episode during which no disorder-specific symptoms are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: During the past 2 months, no significant signs or symptoms of the depressive disturbance are present.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more false beliefs that are firmly held despite clear or reasonable evidence to the contrary.
subcriteria: 1. The beliefs are not ordinarily accepted by other members of the person's culture or subculture.
2. The beliefs are not accounted for by the individual's cultural or religious background.

Persecutory Delusions.title: Persecutory Delusions

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual holds a fixed, false belief that they are going to be harmed, harassed, or persecuted by an individual, organization, or other group.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by suspiciousness, hostility, or hypervigilance.

Referential Delusions.title: Referential Delusions

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of delusions in which the individual believes that certain gestures, comments, or environmental cues are specifically directed at oneself.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by suspiciousness or paranoid ideation
Can occur in the context of psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia

Grandiose Delusions.title: Grandiose Delusions

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of delusions involving the belief that one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by elevated mood or increased goal-directed activity.
Individuals may act in accordance with their delusional beliefs.
differentialDiagnosis: Bipolar I Disorder, manic episode with psychotic features

Erotomanic Delusions.title: Erotomanic Type Delusional Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one or more delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
subcriteria: 1. The central theme of the delusion is that another person is in love with the individual.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

associatedFeatures: Legal difficulties related to the delusional belief
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Nihilistic Delusions.title: Nihilistic Delusions

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of a fixed, false belief that a major catastrophe will occur, despite evidence to the contrary.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of mood disorders with psychotic features, schizophrenia, or severe depressive episodes.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Somatic Delusions.title: Somatic Delusions

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more delusions with a somatic theme (i.e., preoccupations regarding health and organ function).

associatedFeatures: Individuals may be preoccupied with bodily functions, sensations, or perceived medical conditions despite lack of medical evidence.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Delusions that are clearly implausible, not understandable to same-culture peers, and do not derive from ordinary life experiences.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more delusions that are nonbizarre in nature.
subcriteria: 1. The delusions involve situations that could occur in real life (e.g., being followed, poisoned, infected, loved at a distance, or deceived by a spouse or lover, or having a disease).
2. The delusions are false but are not clearly implausible, not bizarre, and not derived from ordinary life experiences.

Thought Withdrawal.title: Thought Withdrawal

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual experiences the belief that their thoughts have been removed from their mind by some outside force.

associatedFeatures: May occur as part of a delusional syndrome, particularly in schizophrenia.
Often accompanied by other passivity phenomena such as thought insertion or thought broadcasting.

Thought Insertion.title: Thought Insertion

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual experiences the belief that thoughts that are not their own have been inserted into their mind by an external force.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by other delusional beliefs, such as thought withdrawal or thought broadcasting.
Frequently observed in psychotic disorders, particularly schizophrenia.

Delusions of Control.title: Delusions of Control

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of delusions in which the individual believes that their body or actions are being acted on or manipulated by some outside force.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
Often accompanied by other types of delusions or hallucinations.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Perceptions of objects or events that are not present.
subcriteria: 1. May involve hearing voices (auditory hallucinations).
2. May involve seeing things that are not there (visual hallucinations).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Hallucinations are not attributable to the effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Auditory Hallucinations.title: Auditory Hallucinations

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of hallucinations involving hearing voices or sounds, typically experienced as voices distinct from the individual's own thoughts.

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by distress or behavioral responses to the perceived voices.
Often reported as clear, distinct, and perceived as external or internal.
comorbidity: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Disorganized thinking, typically inferred from speech, as evidenced by at least one of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Frequent derailment or switching from one topic to another.
2. Tangentiality, such as answers to questions that are obliquely related or completely unrelated.
3. Incoherence or 'word salad,' where speech is so severely disorganized that it is nearly incomprehensible.

Derailment.title: Derailment

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A symptom of disorganized thinking characterized by frequent shifts from one topic to another during conversation.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in individuals with psychotic disorders, such as schizophrenia.
Often accompanied by other symptoms of disorganized speech, such as tangentiality or incoherence.

Loose Associations.title: Loose Associations

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A symptom of disorganized thinking where ideas are only loosely connected.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.

Tangentiality.title: Tangentiality

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A symptom of disorganized thinking characterized by answers to questions that are obliquely related or completely unrelated to the question asked.

associatedFeatures: Frequently observed in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
May co-occur with other thought process disturbances, such as derailment or loosening of associations.

Incoherence (Word Salad).title: Incoherence (Word Salad)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Speech is so severely disorganized that it is nearly incomprehensible, resembling receptive aphasia.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in severe psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
Often accompanied by other disorganized behaviors or thought disturbances.

Grossly Disorganized or Abnormal Motor B.title: Grossly Disorganized or Abnormal Motor Behavior

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Motor behavior that is markedly disorganized or abnormal, ranging from childlike silliness to unpredictable agitation and difficulties in goal-directed behavior.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A lack of, or very minimal, verbal response that is not due to aphasia.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A state of no psychomotor activity in which the individual is not actively relating to the environment.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Purposeless and excessive motor activity without obvious cause.

Stereotyped Movements.title: Stereotypic Movement Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Repetitive, seemingly driven, and apparently purposeless motor behavior (e.g., hand shaking or waving, body rocking, head banging, self-biting, hitting own body).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The repetitive motor behavior interferes with social, academic, or other activities and may result in self-injury.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Onset is in the early developmental period.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The repetitive motor behavior is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or neurological condition and is not better explained by another neurodevelopmental or mental disorder.

specifiers: Associated with a known medical or genetic condition, neurodevelopmental disorder, or environmental factor
associatedFeatures: May be associated with intellectual disability

Negative Symptoms.title: Negative Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of symptoms that reflect a decrease or loss of normal functions.
subcriteria: 1. Diminished emotional expression (e.g., reduced facial expression, eye contact, intonation of speech, or movements of the hand, head, and face that normally give emotional emphasis to speech).
2. Avolition (decreased motivation to initiate and perform self-directed purposeful activities).
3. Alogia (diminished speech output).
4. Anhedonia (decreased ability to experience pleasure from positive stimuli or a degradation in the recollection of pleasure previously experienced).

associatedFeatures: May be associated with social withdrawal, poor self-care, and functional impairment.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Reductions in the expression of emotions in the face, eye contact, speech intonation, and movements that normally convey emotion.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A decrease in the motivation to initiate and perform self-directed purposeful activities.

Alogia.title: Alogia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A marked poverty of speech that is not attributable to language barriers.
subcriteria: 1. Responses to questions are brief and unelaborated.
2. Spontaneous speech is markedly reduced in amount and content.

associatedFeatures: Often observed as a negative symptom in schizophrenia.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Apparent lack of interest in social interactions.

Schizotypal Personality Disorder.title: Schizotypal Personality Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive pattern of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Ideas of reference (excluding delusions of reference).
2. Odd beliefs or magical thinking that influences behavior and is inconsistent with subcultural norms (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, or 'sixth sense').
3. Unusual perceptual experiences, including bodily illusions.
4. Odd thinking and speech (e.g., vague, circumstantial, metaphorical, overelaborate, or stereotyped).
5. Suspiciousness or paranoid ideation.
6. Inappropriate or constricted affect.
7. Behavior or appearance that is odd, eccentric, or peculiar.
8. Lack of close friends or confidants other than first-degree relatives.
9. Excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity and tends to be associated with paranoid fears rather than negative judgments about self.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Does not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia, a bipolar disorder or depressive disorder with psychotic features, another psychotic disorder, or autism spectrum disorder.

Schizotypal Personality Disorder.timeFrame: Beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts.
associatedFeatures: May experience transient psychotic episodes in response to stress.
May have odd or peculiar mannerisms and appearance.
May have difficulties with attention and memory.

Brief Psychotic Disorder.title: Brief Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one (or more) of the following symptoms. At least one of these must be (1), (2), or (3):
subcriteria: 1. Delusions.
2. Hallucinations.
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence).
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Duration of an episode of the disturbance is at least 1 day but less than 1 month, with eventual full return to premorbid level of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features or another psychotic disorder such as schizophrenia or catatonia and is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Brief Psychotic Disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 day but less than 1 month
differentialDiagnosis: Other psychotic disorders (e.g., Schizophrenia, Schizophreniform Disorder)

Schizophreniform Disorder.title: Schizophreniform Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Two (or more) of the following, each present for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated). At least one of these must be (1), (2), or (3):
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
5. Negative symptoms (i.e., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: An episode of the disorder lasts at least 1 month but less than 6 months. When diagnosis must be made without waiting for recovery, it should be qualified as 'provisional.'

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Schizoaffective disorder and depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features have been ruled out because either (1) no major depressive or manic episodes have occurred concurrently with the active-phase symptoms, or (2) if mood episodes have occurred during active-phase symptoms, they have been present for a minority of the total duration of the active and residual periods of the illness.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

Schizophreniform Disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 month but less than 6 months
associatedFeatures: Impaired social or occupational functioning may be present but is not required
Mood symptoms may occur but do not predominate
differentialDiagnosis: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

Substance/Medication-Induced Psychotic D.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or both of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions.
2. Hallucinations.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both (1) and (2):
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the symptoms in Criterion A.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a psychotic disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent psychotic disorder could include: the symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use; the symptoms persist for a substantial period (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication; or there is other evidence of an independent non–substance/medication-induced psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Substance/Medication-Induced Psychotic D.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or soon after substance intoxication, withdrawal, or exposure.
associatedFeatures: May include disorganized thinking, agitation, or mood symptoms.

Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medica.title: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Prominent hallucinations or delusions are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: May include disorganized thinking or behavior depending on the underlying medical condition
Insight into the psychotic symptoms is often limited

Catatonia Associated with Another Mental.title: Catatonia Associated with Another Mental Disorder (Catatonia Specifier)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical picture is dominated by three (or more) of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Stupor (i.e., no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment)
2. Catalepsy (i.e., passive induction of a posture held against gravity)
3. Waxy flexibility (i.e., slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner)
4. Mutism (i.e., no, or very little, verbal response [exclude if known aphasia])
5. Negativism (i.e., opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli)
6. Posturing (i.e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity)
7. Mannerism (i.e., odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions)
8. Stereotypy (i.e., repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements)
9. Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
10. Grimacing
11. Echolalia (i.e., mimicking another's speech)
12. Echopraxia (i.e., mimicking another's movements)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The catatonic symptoms occur in the context of another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder, psychotic disorder, autism spectrum disorder).

associatedFeatures: May be associated with mood disorders, psychotic disorders, or other medical conditions.
differentialDiagnosis: Catatonia due to another medical condition
comorbidity: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders

Catatonic Disorder Due to Another Medica.title: Catatonic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical picture is dominated by three (or more) of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Stupor (i.e., no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment)
2. Catalepsy (i.e., passive induction of a posture held against gravity)
3. Waxy flexibility (i.e., slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner)
4. Mutism (i.e., little or no verbal response [exclude if known aphasia])
5. Negativism (i.e., opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli)
6. Posturing (i.e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity)
7. Mannerism (i.e., odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions)
8. Stereotypy (i.e., repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements)
9. Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
10. Grimacing
11. Echolalia (i.e., mimicking another's speech)
12. Echopraxia (i.e., mimicking another's movements)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., a manic episode).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: May include dehydration, malnutrition, or exhaustion due to decreased motor activity
May be associated with underlying medical conditions such as neurological, metabolic, or infectious diseases
differentialDiagnosis: Other mental disorders with catatonic features (e.g., Schizophrenia, Bipolar Disorder)
comorbidity: Medical conditions such as encephalitis, metabolic imbalances, or autoimmune disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical presentation is characterized by catatonic symptoms (such as stupor, catalepsy, waxy flexibility, mutism, negativism, posturing, mannerism, stereotypy, agitation, grimacing, echolalia, or echopraxia) that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The underlying medical, psychiatric, or substance-related cause of the catatonic symptoms is unclear, full criteria for catatonia associated with another mental disorder, due to a medical condition, or substance-induced catatonia are not met, or there is insufficient information to make a more specific diagnosis.

Other Specified Schizophrenia Spectrum a.title: Other Specified Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning predominate.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The full criteria for any of the disorders in the schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders diagnostic class are not met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses to communicate the specific reason that the presentation does not meet the criteria for any specific schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorder (e.g., persistent auditory hallucinations in the absence of other symptoms).

Unspecified Schizophrenia Spectrum and O.title: Unspecified Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Full criteria are not met for any specific schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses not to specify the reason that the criteria are not met for a specific disorder.

Prodromal Period.title: Prodromal Period

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of some symptoms related to a specific disorder, but not sufficient in number, severity, or duration to meet full diagnostic criteria.

Prodromal Period.timeFrame: Prior to the full onset of the disorder
differentialDiagnosis: Normal variations in mood or behavior
Other mental disorders with overlapping early symptoms

Residual Period.title: Residual Period

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The period follows the active phase of a disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Some symptoms of the disorder may persist but are less severe than during the active phase.

Residual Period.timeFrame: After the resolution of the active phase
associatedFeatures: Symptoms may include mild or subthreshold manifestations of the disorder.

Formal Thought Disorder.title: Formal Thought Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Disturbance in the organization and expression of thought, typically inferred from disorganized speech.

associatedFeatures: May include derailment, tangentiality, incoherence, or illogicality.
comorbidity: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Receptive Aphasia.title: Receptive Aphasia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent impairment in language comprehension.
subcriteria: 1. Difficulty understanding spoken or written language.
2. Speech output is fluent but may be nonsensical or contain paraphasic errors.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The language disturbance causes clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to sensory deficits, intellectual disability, or another medical or neurological condition.

associatedFeatures: May include unawareness of language deficits (anosognosia)

Sensorium.title: Sensorium

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is an overall state of cognitive functioning, particularly regarding awareness and orientation.

associatedFeatures: May be assessed in the context of mental status examinations.
Alterations may indicate underlying neurological or psychiatric conditions.

Hypnagogic Hallucinations.title: Hypnagogic Hallucinations

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Hallucinations occur during the transition from wakefulness to sleep (while falling asleep).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The hallucinations are not attributable to a medical condition, substance use, or a mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Considered within the range of normal experience
May include visual, auditory, or tactile phenomena
differentialDiagnosis: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Hypnopompic Hallucinations.title: Hypnopompic Hallucinations

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Hallucinations occur during the transition from sleep to wakefulness.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The hallucinations are not attributable to a medical condition, substance use, or a mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Considered within the range of normal experience
May involve visual, auditory, or tactile phenomena
differentialDiagnosis: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Schizotypal (Personality) Disorder.title: Schizotypal (Personality) Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive pattern of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Ideas of reference (excluding delusions of reference).
2. Odd beliefs or magical thinking that influences behavior and is inconsistent with subcultural norms (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, or 'sixth sense').
3. Unusual perceptual experiences, including bodily illusions.
4. Odd thinking and speech (e.g., vague, circumstantial, metaphorical, overelaborate, or stereotyped).
5. Suspiciousness or paranoid ideation.
6. Inappropriate or constricted affect.
7. Behavior or appearance that is odd, eccentric, or peculiar.
8. Lack of close friends or confidants other than first-degree relatives.
9. Excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity and tends to be associated with paranoid fears rather than negative judgments about self.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Does not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia, a bipolar disorder or depressive disorder with psychotic features, another psychotic disorder, or autism spectrum disorder.

Schizotypal (Personality) Disorder.timeFrame: Beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts.
associatedFeatures: May experience transient psychotic episodes in response to stress.
May have odd or eccentric mannerisms and appearance.
May have difficulties with attention and memory.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A false belief based on incorrect inference about external reality, firmly sustained despite clear evidence to the contrary.
subcriteria: 1. The belief is not ordinarily accepted by other members of the person's culture or subculture.
2. The belief is not accounted for by the individual's cultural or religious background.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A perception-like experience that occurs without an external stimulus (e.g., hearing voices or seeing things that are not present).

Erotomanic Type.title: Delusional Disorder, Erotomanic Type

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
subcriteria: 1. The central theme of the delusion is that another person, usually of higher status, is in love with the individual.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

associatedFeatures: Legal difficulties related to the delusional belief

Grandiose Type.title: Delusional Disorder, Grandiose Type

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
subcriteria: 1. The central theme of the delusion(s) is the conviction of having some great talent, insight, or having made an important discovery.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

associatedFeatures: May present with irritability or argumentative behavior related to the delusional beliefs.

Jealous Type.title: Delusional Disorder, Jealous Type

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
subcriteria: 1. The central theme of the delusion is that one's spouse or lover is unfaithful.
2. The belief is based on incorrect inferences and is not substantiated by evidence.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Potential for violence toward partner or perceived rival
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Somatic Type.title: Delusional Disorder, Somatic Type

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

associatedFeatures: Preoccupation with bodily functions or sensations
Repeated medical consultations despite negative findings
Conviction of infestation, foul odor, or malfunctioning body parts

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one or more delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Unspecified Type.title: Delusional Disorder, Unspecified Type

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Criterion A for schizophrenia has never been met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the impact of the delusion(s) or its ramifications, functioning is not markedly impaired, and behavior is not obviously bizarre or odd.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as body dysmorphic disorder or obsessive-compulsive disorder.

specifiers: first episode, currently in partial remission
first episode, currently in full remission
multiple episodes, currently in partial remission
multiple episodes, currently in full remission
associatedFeatures: Mood disturbances may be present but are usually brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder or Bipolar Disorder with psychotic features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Delusions are clearly implausible, not understandable, and not derived from ordinary life experiences.

First Episode, Currently in Acute Episod.title: First Episode, Currently in Acute Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The first manifestation of the disorder meets full diagnostic criteria.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms are currently present.

First Episode, Currently in Partial Remi.title: First Episode, Currently in Partial Remission

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual previously met full criteria for the disorder during a first episode.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Currently, only some diagnostic criteria for the disorder are still met, or symptoms are present at subthreshold levels.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: There has been a clinically significant improvement compared to the previous episode.

First Episode, Currently in Full Remissi.title: First Episode, Currently in Full Remission

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: No disorder-specific symptoms are present following a previous episode.

Multiple Episodes, Currently in Acute Ep.title: Multiple Episodes, Currently in Acute Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: More than one episode of the disorder has occurred.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Current symptoms meet full diagnostic criteria for an episode.

Multiple Episodes, Currently in Partial.title: Multiple Episodes, Currently in Partial Remission

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: More than one episode of the disorder has occurred.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Current symptoms only partially meet the full criteria for an episode.

Multiple Episodes, Currently in Full Rem.title: Multiple Episodes, Currently in Full Remission

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: More than one episode of the disorder has occurred.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: No current symptoms specific to the disorder are present.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms meeting full diagnostic criteria are present for the majority of the illness course, with only brief periods of subthreshold symptoms.

Factual Insight.title: Factual Insight

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual is able to accurately state that other people consider their beliefs to be irrational or unfounded.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The individual does not personally accept or agree with the view that their beliefs are irrational.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in individuals with delusional or obsessive-compulsive disorders.
Distinguishes between acknowledgment of external perspectives and personal conviction.
differentialDiagnosis: Absent insight (complete lack of awareness of irrationality)
True insight (personal acceptance that beliefs are irrational)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Marked ability to perform and fulfill normal social roles and relationships.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Impairment in psychosocial functioning may be present in the context of psychiatric disorders.

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD).title: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both.
subcriteria: 1. Obsessions are defined by (a) recurrent and persistent thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced as intrusive and unwanted, and (b) the individual attempts to ignore or suppress such thoughts, urges, or images, or to neutralize them with some other thought or action (i.e., by performing a compulsion).

2. Compulsions are defined by (a) repetitive behaviors (e.g., hand washing, ordering, checking) or mental acts (e.g., praying, counting, repeating words silently) that the individual feels driven to perform in response to an obsession or according to rules that must be applied rigidly, and (b) the behaviors or mental acts are aimed at preventing or reducing anxiety or distress, or preventing some dreaded event or situation; however, these behaviors or mental acts are not connected in a realistic way with what they are designed to neutralize or prevent, or are clearly excessive.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The obsessions or compulsions are time-consuming (e.g., take more than 1 hour per day) or cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The obsessive-compulsive symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder (e.g., excessive worries, as in generalized anxiety disorder; preoccupation with appearance, as in body dysmorphic disorder; difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, as in hoarding disorder; hair pulling, as in trichotillomania; skin picking, as in excoriation disorder; stereotypies, as in stereotypic movement disorder; ritualized eating behavior, as in eating disorders; preoccupation with substances or gambling, as in substance-related and addictive disorders; preoccupation with having an illness, as in illness anxiety disorder; sexual urges or fantasies, as in paraphilic disorders; impulses, as in disruptive, impulse-control, and conduct disorders).

associatedFeatures: Avoidance of situations that trigger obsessions or compulsions
High levels of distress or anxiety

Body Dysmorphic Disorder.title: Body Dysmorphic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear slight to others.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: At some point during the course of the disorder, the individual has performed repetitive behaviors (e.g., mirror checking, excessive grooming, skin picking, reassurance seeking) or mental acts (e.g., comparing his or her appearance with that of others) in response to the appearance concerns.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The preoccupation causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The appearance preoccupation is not better explained by concerns with body fat or weight in an individual whose symptoms meet diagnostic criteria for an eating disorder.

associatedFeatures: High rates of suicidal ideation and attempts

Absent Insight/Delusional Beliefs Specif.title: Absent Insight/Delusional Beliefs Specifier

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual is completely convinced that their beliefs (related to obsessive-compulsive disorder or body dysmorphic disorder) are true.
subcriteria: 1. There is a persistent lack of insight regarding the irrationality or inaccuracy of these beliefs.
2. The conviction is held with delusional intensity.

associatedFeatures: May be associated with poorer treatment response.
Frequently observed in severe presentations of obsessive-compulsive disorder or body dysmorphic disorder.
differentialDiagnosis: Other obsessive-compulsive and related disorders with varying levels of insight

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of significant cognitive decline from a previous level of performance in one or more cognitive domains (complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor, or social cognition) based on:
subcriteria: 1. Concern of the individual, a knowledgeable informant, or the clinician that there has been a significant decline in cognitive function; and
2. A substantial impairment in cognitive performance, preferably documented by standardized neuropsychological testing or, in its absence, another quantified clinical assessment.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits interfere with independence in everyday activities (i.e., at a minimum, requiring assistance with complex instrumental activities of daily living such as paying bills or managing medications).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits do not occur exclusively in the context of delirium.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder, schizophrenia).

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Speech that is difficult to follow due to incoherence, derailment, or loose associations, reflecting disorganized thinking.

Grossly disorganized behavior.title: Grossly Disorganized Behavior

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Behavior that is markedly abnormal, unpredictable, or inappropriate for the situation.
subcriteria: 1. Includes difficulties in performing daily activities.
2. May manifest as unpredictable agitation, inappropriate emotional responses, or disorganized motor activity.

associatedFeatures: Impaired ability to maintain personal hygiene

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Marked decrease in reactivity to the environment.
subcriteria: 1. Stupor (no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment).
2. Mutism (little or no verbal response).
3. Negativism (opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli).
4. Rigidity (maintaining a rigid posture against attempts to be moved).
5. Excessive motor activity without apparent purpose (not influenced by external stimuli).

Negative symptoms.title: Negative Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of symptoms that reflect a decrease or loss of normal functions.
subcriteria: 1. Reduced emotional expression (e.g., diminished facial expression, voice intonation, or gestures).
2. Lack of motivation (avolition).
3. Social withdrawal or diminished social engagement.

associatedFeatures: May include diminished speech output (alogia) and reduced ability to experience pleasure (anhedonia).

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The level of psychological, social, and occupational functioning prior to the onset of a mental disorder.

Brief psychotic disorder.title: Brief Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one (or more) of the following symptoms. At least one of these must be (1), (2), or (3):
subcriteria: 1. Delusions.
2. Hallucinations.
3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence).
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Duration of an episode of the disturbance is at least 1 day but less than 1 month, with eventual full return to premorbid level of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features or another psychotic disorder (e.g., schizophrenia or catatonia) and is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

Brief psychotic disorder.timeFrame: At least 1 day but less than 1 month
associatedFeatures: Rapid shifts from one intense affect to another
Heightened risk of suicidal behavior, especially during the acute episode
differentialDiagnosis: Other medical conditions with psychotic symptoms
Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

Mood episode.title: Mood Episode

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period characterized by a significant disturbance in mood.
subcriteria: 1. The disturbance may present as either elevated, expansive, or irritable mood (mania or hypomania), or as depressed mood (depressive episode).
2. The episode may occur in the context of mood disorders (e.g., Major Depressive Disorder, Bipolar Disorder) or psychotic disorders.

associatedFeatures: Changes in energy, activity, or cognitive functioning
Impairment in social or occupational functioning

Prodrome.title: Prodrome

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of early signs or symptoms indicating the onset of a disease, occurring before the development of more diagnostically specific symptoms.

associatedFeatures: Symptoms may be nonspecific and can include changes in mood, behavior, cognition, or physical state.

Substance/medication-induced psychotic d.title: Substance/Medication-Induced Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or both of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions.
2. Hallucinations.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings of both (1) and (2):
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms in Criterion A developed during or soon after substance intoxication or withdrawal or after exposure to a medication.
2. The involved substance/medication is capable of producing the symptoms in Criterion A.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by a psychotic disorder that is not substance/medication-induced. Such evidence of an independent psychotic disorder could include:
subcriteria: 1. The symptoms preceded the onset of the substance/medication use.
2. The symptoms persist for a substantial period of time (e.g., about 1 month) after the cessation of acute withdrawal or severe intoxication.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Substance/medication-induced psychotic d.timeFrame: Symptoms develop during or soon after substance intoxication, withdrawal, or exposure.
associatedFeatures: May include agitation, disorganized thinking, or mood symptoms depending on the substance involved.

Factitious disorder.title: Factitious Disorder Imposed on Self

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Falsification of physical or psychological signs or symptoms, or induction of injury or disease, associated with identified deception.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The individual presents himself or herself to others as ill, impaired, or injured.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The deceptive behavior is evident even in the absence of obvious external rewards.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The behavior is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as delusional disorder or another psychotic disorder.

associatedFeatures: Extensive knowledge of medical terminology and hospital routines
History of multiple surgeries or procedures

Malingering.title: Malingering

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Intentional production or feigning of physical or psychological symptoms.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The motivation for the behavior involves external incentives (e.g., avoiding military duty, avoiding work, obtaining financial compensation, evading criminal prosecution, or obtaining drugs).

associatedFeatures: May present with inconsistent medical history
Symptoms may not conform to recognized medical conditions
Marked discrepancy between claimed distress and objective findings

Schizotypal personality disorder.title: Schizotypal Personality Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive pattern of social and interpersonal deficits marked by acute discomfort with, and reduced capacity for, close relationships as well as by cognitive or perceptual distortions and eccentricities of behavior, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by five (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Ideas of reference (excluding delusions of reference).
2. Odd beliefs or magical thinking that influences behavior and is inconsistent with subcultural norms (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, or 'sixth sense').
3. Unusual perceptual experiences, including bodily illusions.
4. Odd thinking and speech (e.g., vague, circumstantial, metaphorical, overelaborate, or stereotyped).
5. Suspiciousness or paranoid ideation.
6. Inappropriate or constricted affect.
7. Behavior or appearance that is odd, eccentric, or peculiar.
8. Lack of close friends or confidants other than first-degree relatives.
9. Excessive social anxiety that does not diminish with familiarity and tends to be associated with paranoid fears rather than negative judgments about self.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Does not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia, a bipolar disorder or depressive disorder with psychotic features, another psychotic disorder, or autism spectrum disorder.

Schizotypal personality disorder.timeFrame: Beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts.
associatedFeatures: May experience transient psychotic episodes in response to stress.
May have odd or eccentric mannerisms and appearance.
May have difficulties with attention and memory.

Perceptual dysregulation.title: Perceptual Dysregulation

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent or recurrent experiences of unusual or distorted perceptions.
subcriteria: 1. Hearing voices or sounds that are not present (auditory hallucinations).
2. Seeing things that are not there (visual hallucinations).
3. Other perceptual distortions not attributable to external stimuli.

associatedFeatures: May be associated with dissociative experiences.
Can occur in the context of personality pathology.
differentialDiagnosis: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Negative affectivity.title: Negative Affectivity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A pervasive pattern of frequent and intense experiences of negative emotions, beginning by early adulthood and present in a variety of contexts, as indicated by one (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Experiences anxiety, worry, or fear that is difficult to control.
2. Exhibits frequent feelings of depression, sadness, or hopelessness.
3. Displays suspiciousness or mistrust of others.

comorbidity: Other personality trait domains (e.g., Detachment, Disinhibition)

With marked stressor(s) (brief reactive.title: Brief Psychotic Disorder
associatedFeatures: A specifier indicating that symptoms occur in response to events that would be markedly stressful to almost anyone in similar circumstances.

criteria.label: Specifier Definition
criteria.text: This specifier is used when at least two of the following features are present: onset of prominent psychotic symptoms within 4 weeks of the first noticeable change in usual behavior or functioning; confusion or perplexity at the height of the psychotic episode; good premorbid social and occupational functioning; and absence of blunted or flat affect.

Without good prognostic features.title: Schizophreniform Disorder, Without Good Prognostic Features

criteria.label: Specifier Definition
criteria.text: This specifier is used when two or more of the following good prognostic features are not present: (1) onset of prominent psychotic symptoms within 4 weeks of the first noticeable change in usual behavior or functioning; (2) confusion or perplexity at the height of the psychotic episode; (3) good premorbid social and occupational functioning; and (4) absence of blunted or flat affect.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A quantitative assessment of the primary symptoms of psychosis is required.
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech
4. Abnormal psychomotor behavior
5. Negative symptoms

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Each symptom is rated on a 5-point scale from 0 (not present) to 4 (present and severe).

Abnormal psychomotor behavior.title: Abnormal Psychomotor Behavior

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of unusual movements or behaviors.
subcriteria: 1. Psychomotor agitation (e.g., restlessness, pacing, inability to sit still).
2. Psychomotor retardation (e.g., slowed movements, decreased spontaneous movement).

associatedFeatures: Frequently observed in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
May include stereotyped movements, grimacing, or catatonic behaviors.
comorbidity: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Prodromal phase.title: Prodromal Phase

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of subtle or nonspecific symptoms that precede the onset of the active phase of a mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Mild disturbances in mood, cognition, or behavior

Active phase.title: Active Phase of Schizophrenia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of characteristic symptoms of schizophrenia.
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior

Active phase.timeFrame: During the period when characteristic symptoms are most prominent
associatedFeatures: Impairment in social or occupational functioning

Residual phase.title: Residual Phase

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The period following the active phase of a psychotic disorder during which some symptoms may persist but are less severe or attenuated.

differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is improvement following a previous episode of the disorder, but some symptoms of the disorder are still present.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period following a previous episode during which no disorder-specific symptoms are present.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms fulfilling diagnostic criteria are present for the majority of the illness duration, with only brief subthreshold periods.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The initial manifestation of a disorder meeting the defining diagnostic symptom and time criteria.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There have been at least two distinct episodes of the disorder.
subcriteria: 1. Each episode is separated by at least one period of remission.
2. At least one relapse has occurred between episodes.

Cognitive impairment.title: Cognitive Impairment

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Deficits in one or more cognitive domains, including memory, attention, language, executive function, or processing speed.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits are present in the context of a primary psychiatric disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) and are not better explained by another medical condition, substance use, or developmental disorder.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits contribute to functional impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: Cognitive impairment is common in schizophrenia and may be present before the onset of psychotic symptoms.
Deficits may persist even when other symptoms are in remission.

Prodromal symptoms.title: Prodromal Symptoms of Schizophrenia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of early signs or symptoms that precede the active phase of schizophrenia.
subcriteria: 1. Mild or subthreshold hallucinations (e.g., vague perceptual disturbances).
2. Mild or subthreshold delusions (e.g., suspiciousness or odd beliefs not reaching delusional intensity).
3. Negative symptoms (e.g., social withdrawal, diminished emotional expression, or avolition).

Prodromal symptoms.timeFrame: Symptoms are present prior to the onset of the active phase of schizophrenia.
associatedFeatures: Impairment in social, academic, or occupational functioning
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Residual symptoms.title: Residual Symptoms of Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of symptoms that persist following the resolution of the acute phase of a psychotic disorder.
subcriteria: 1. Milder or subthreshold psychotic symptoms (e.g., attenuated delusions, hallucinations, or disorganized thinking).
2. Negative symptoms (e.g., diminished emotional expression, avolition, anhedonia).

Residual symptoms.timeFrame: Following the acute phase of a psychotic disorder
associatedFeatures: Impairment in social or occupational functioning
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Ideas of reference.title: Ideas of Reference

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual experiences the belief that unrelated events, objects, or people have a particular and unusual significance specifically for oneself.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of psychotic disorders, personality disorders, or during periods of high stress.

Magical thinking.title: Magical Thinking

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent belief that one's thoughts, words, or actions can cause or prevent specific outcomes in a manner that defies conventional laws of causality.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in individuals with schizotypal personality disorder, obsessive-compulsive disorder, or during normal childhood development.

Disorganized behavior.title: Disorganized Behavior

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Behavior that is markedly inappropriate, unpredictable, or lacking in goal-directedness.
subcriteria: 1. Includes agitation.
2. Includes silliness.
3. Includes difficulty performing daily activities.

associatedFeatures: May be observed as difficulty maintaining personal hygiene.

Mood symptoms.title: Mood Symptoms Associated with Schizophrenia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Emotional disturbances such as depression, anxiety, or mania are present during the course of schizophrenia.
subcriteria: 1. Depressive symptoms (e.g., persistent sadness, loss of interest).
2. Anxious symptoms (e.g., excessive worry, restlessness).
3. Manic symptoms (e.g., elevated mood, increased activity).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Mood symptoms occur concurrently with psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations).

differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

Psychotic mood disorder.title: Psychotic Mood Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual meets criteria for a mood episode (e.g., major depressive episode, manic episode, or mixed episode).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Psychotic features (e.g., delusions or hallucinations) are present, but occur exclusively during mood episodes.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The psychotic symptoms are not better explained by a primary psychotic disorder (e.g., schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder) or due to the direct physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Psychotic mood disorder.timeFrame: During the duration of the mood episode

Inappropriate affect.title: Inappropriate Affect

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Emotional responses that are incongruent with the situation or context (e.g., laughing without an appropriate stimulus).

associatedFeatures: May be observed in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
Can occur alongside other disturbances of affect, such as flat or blunted affect.
comorbidity: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A general state of unease or dissatisfaction is present.
subcriteria: 1. The mood may include feelings of depression.
2. The mood may include anxiety.
3. The mood may include anger.

Depersonalization.title: Depersonalization

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent or recurrent experiences of depersonalization, i.e., experiences of unreality, detachment, or being an outside observer with respect to one's thoughts, feelings, sensations, body, or actions (e.g., perceptual alterations, a sense of unreality or of being in a dream, or a sense of detachment from one's self or body).

differentialDiagnosis: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A feeling that the external world is unreal or strange.

Somatic concerns.title: Somatic Concerns

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Preoccupation with physical health or bodily functions.
subcriteria: 1. The preoccupation may reach delusional intensity.
2. The concerns are not better explained by another medical or mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: May include frequent medical visits or requests for tests.

Cognitive deficits.title: Cognitive Deficits

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Impairments in one or more cognitive domains, such as memory, attention, language, or executive function.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits are persistent and represent a decline from a previous level of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The deficits are not better explained by another mental disorder, medical condition, or the effects of a substance.

associatedFeatures: Frequently observed in schizophrenia and may contribute to functional impairment.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The ability to consciously recall facts and events.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The capacity to hold and manipulate information in mind over short periods.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent difficulties in higher-level cognitive processes that interfere with daily functioning.
subcriteria: 1. Impairment in planning activities or tasks.
2. Difficulty with decision-making.
3. Problems with problem-solving.
4. Deficits in self-control or inhibition.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The executive function deficits are not better explained by another mental disorder, neurological condition, or the effects of a substance.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Processing speed is characterized by the rate at which an individual can perceive, understand, and respond to information.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The way the nervous system receives and interprets sensory information from the environment.

Inhibitory capacity.title: Inhibitory Capacity

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Marked ability to suppress irrelevant or inappropriate thoughts, impulses, or actions.

associatedFeatures: May contribute to adaptive functioning by preventing impulsive behaviors.
Deficits may be observed in various neurodevelopmental and psychiatric disorders.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The ability to focus selectively on specific stimuli or tasks.

Social cognition.title: Social Cognition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent difficulties in the mental processes involved in perceiving, interpreting, and responding to the intentions, emotions, and behaviors of others.

associatedFeatures: May include misinterpretation of social cues
Difficulty understanding others' emotions or intentions

Theory of mind.title: Theory of Mind Deficit

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent difficulty in understanding and inferring the mental states, intentions, and perspectives of other people.

associatedFeatures: May manifest as challenges in social communication and interaction
Frequently observed in neurodevelopmental disorders such as Autism Spectrum Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Awareness and understanding of having a mental disorder and its symptoms.

Anosognosia.title: Anosognosia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A lack of awareness or insight into one's own mental health condition.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The lack of awareness is not better explained by cognitive impairment, delirium, or another medical condition.

associatedFeatures: Frequently observed in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
May contribute to poor treatment adherence.
differentialDiagnosis: Denial due to psychological defense mechanisms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent feelings or behaviors characterized by anger, opposition, or aggression directed toward others.

Aggression.title: Aggression

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Hostile or violent behavior directed toward others.

associatedFeatures: May be more common in certain subgroups of individuals with schizophrenia.

Neurological soft signs.title: Neurological Soft Signs

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of minor neurological abnormalities not attributable to a known neurological disorder.
subcriteria: 1. Impaired motor coordination (e.g., difficulty with rapid alternating movements, balance issues).
2. Impaired sensory integration (e.g., difficulty integrating visual, tactile, or proprioceptive information).
3. Impaired sequencing of movements (e.g., difficulty performing complex motor tasks in the correct order).

associatedFeatures: Often observed in individuals with schizophrenia.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The ability to execute smooth, accurate, and controlled movements.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The process by which the brain combines information from different sensory modalities.

Motor sequencing.title: Motor Sequencing

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent difficulty in performing a series of movements in a specific order.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in developmental coordination disorder, apraxia, or neurological conditions.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The age or period when the first symptoms of a disorder appear.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A worsening or increase in the severity of symptoms.

Positive symptoms.title: Positive Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of symptoms that reflect an excess or distortion of normal functions.
subcriteria: 1. Hallucinations
2. Delusions
3. Disorganized speech
4. Disorganized or catatonic behavior

associatedFeatures: May be accompanied by agitation or inappropriate affect

Premorbid adjustment.title: Premorbid Adjustment

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of the individual's level of psychological and social functioning prior to the onset of a mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Assesses baseline functioning in areas such as interpersonal relationships, academic or occupational performance, and self-care prior to illness onset.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Characteristics or conditions that increase the likelihood of developing a disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Inherited characteristics that contribute to the risk of developing a disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of specific genetic variants that increase the likelihood of developing a disorder.

Hypoxia.title: Hypoxia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A deficiency in the amount of oxygen reaching the tissues.

associatedFeatures: When occurring during pregnancy or birth, hypoxia can be a risk factor for schizophrenia.

Perinatal adversities.title: Perinatal Adversities

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more negative events or conditions occurring around the time of birth.
subcriteria: 1. Perinatal infection (e.g., maternal or neonatal infection).
2. Perinatal malnutrition.
3. Maternal illness during the perinatal period.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: These adversities may increase the risk for the later development of schizophrenia.

associatedFeatures: May include low birth weight, premature birth, or complications during delivery.
differentialDiagnosis: Other environmental risk factors (e.g., childhood trauma)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Beliefs, practices, and norms that influence the expression, recognition, and interpretation of symptoms and behaviors.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of social and economic conditions that influence health, access to care, and the course of a disorder.

Pseudo-hallucination.title: Pseudo-hallucination

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual experiences a perceptual phenomenon similar to a hallucination.
subcriteria: 1. The experience is recognized by the individual as not corresponding to external reality.
2. The individual identifies the experience as a product of their own mind.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of dissociative states or severe stress.
Insight is preserved regarding the unreality of the experience.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A belief that is held with less than delusional intensity but is still unreasonable and sustained.

Psychosis.title: Psychosis

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following symptoms indicating a loss of contact with reality:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions (fixed, false beliefs not amenable to evidence to the contrary)
2. Hallucinations (perception-like experiences without external stimulus)
3. Disorganized thinking (speech)
4. Grossly disorganized or abnormal motor behavior

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder with psychotic features, substance-induced psychotic disorder, or a medical condition).

differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with psychotic features

Disorganization.title: Disorganization

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of disorganized thinking, speech, or behavior.
subcriteria: 1. Disorganized thinking as evidenced by frequent derailment or incoherence.
2. Disorganized speech, such as tangentiality or loose associations.
3. Disorganized or bizarre behavior that is not goal-directed.

associatedFeatures: Often observed in schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders.

Command hallucination.title: Command Hallucination

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of hallucinations in which the individual hears voices that instruct them to perform specific acts.
subcriteria: 1. The voices provide clear commands or instructions.
2. The commands may involve actions that are potentially harmful to self or others.

associatedFeatures: May be associated with increased risk of harm to self or others if the commands are acted upon.
Frequently observed in psychotic disorders such as schizophrenia.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

Obsessive-compulsive disorder.title: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of obsessions, compulsions, or both.
subcriteria: 1. Obsessions are defined by (a) recurrent and persistent thoughts, urges, or images that are experienced as intrusive and unwanted, and (b) the individual attempts to ignore or suppress such thoughts, urges, or images, or to neutralize them with some other thought or action (i.e., by performing a compulsion).

2. Compulsions are defined by (a) repetitive behaviors (e.g., hand washing, ordering, checking) or mental acts (e.g., praying, counting, repeating words silently) that the individual feels driven to perform in response to an obsession or according to rules that must be applied rigidly, and (b) the behaviors or mental acts are aimed at preventing or reducing anxiety or distress, or preventing some dreaded event or situation; however, these behaviors or mental acts are not connected in a realistic way with what they are designed to neutralize or prevent, or are clearly excessive.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The obsessions or compulsions are time-consuming (e.g., take more than 1 hour per day) or cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The obsessive-compulsive symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder (e.g., excessive worries, as in generalized anxiety disorder; preoccupation with appearance, as in body dysmorphic disorder; difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, as in hoarding disorder; hair pulling, as in trichotillomania [hair-pulling disorder]; skin picking, as in excoriation [skin-picking] disorder; stereotypies, as in stereotypic movement disorder; ritualized eating behavior, as in eating disorders; preoccupation with substances or gambling, as in substance-related and addictive disorders; preoccupation with having an illness, as in illness anxiety disorder; sexual urges or fantasies, as in paraphilic disorders; impulses, as in disruptive, impulse-control, and conduct disorders; guilty ruminations, as in major depressive disorder; thought insertion or delusional preoccupations, as in schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders).

associatedFeatures: Avoidance of situations that may trigger obsessions or compulsions
High levels of distress and anxiety
differentialDiagnosis: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

Body dysmorphic disorder.title: Body Dysmorphic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Preoccupation with one or more perceived defects or flaws in physical appearance that are not observable or appear slight to others.

criteria.label: B
