criteria.text: At some point during the course of the disorder, the individual has performed repetitive behaviors (e.g., mirror checking, excessive grooming, skin picking, reassurance seeking) or mental acts (e.g., comparing his or her appearance with that of others) in response to the appearance concerns.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The preoccupation causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The appearance preoccupation is not better explained by concerns with body fat or weight in an individual whose symptoms meet diagnostic criteria for an eating disorder.

associatedFeatures: High levels of anxiety and shame
Repetitive behaviors such as mirror checking or excessive grooming

Posttraumatic stress disorder.title: Posttraumatic Stress Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violence in one (or more) of the following ways:
subcriteria: 1. Directly experiencing the traumatic event(s).
2. Witnessing, in person, the event(s) as it occurred to others.
3. Learning that the traumatic event(s) occurred to a close family member or close friend.
4. Experiencing repeated or extreme exposure to aversive details of the traumatic event(s).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Presence of one (or more) of the following intrusion symptoms associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning after the traumatic event(s) occurred:
subcriteria: 1. Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories of the traumatic event(s).
2. Recurrent distressing dreams in which the content and/or affect of the dream are related to the traumatic event(s).
3. Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring.
4. Intense or prolonged psychological distress at exposure to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s).
5. Marked physiological reactions to internal or external cues that symbolize or resemble an aspect of the traumatic event(s).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Persistent avoidance of stimuli associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by one or both of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Avoidance of or efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s).

2. Avoidance of or efforts to avoid external reminders (people, places, conversations, activities, objects, situations) that arouse distressing memories, thoughts, or feelings about or closely associated with the traumatic event(s).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Negative alterations in cognitions and mood associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning or worsening after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event(s) (typically due to dissociative amnesia and not to other factors such as head injury, alcohol, or drugs).
2. Persistent and exaggerated negative beliefs or expectations about oneself, others, or the world.
3. Persistent, distorted cognitions about the cause or consequences of the traumatic event(s) that lead the individual to blame himself/herself or others.
4. Persistent negative emotional state (e.g., fear, horror, anger, guilt, or shame).
5. Markedly diminished interest or participation in significant activities.
6. Feelings of detachment or estrangement from others.
7. Persistent inability to experience positive emotions (e.g., inability to experience happiness, satisfaction, or loving feelings).

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Marked alterations in arousal and reactivity associated with the traumatic event(s), beginning or worsening after the traumatic event(s) occurred, as evidenced by two (or more) of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Irritable behavior and angry outbursts (with little or no provocation), typically expressed as verbal or physical aggression toward people or objects.
2. Reckless or self-destructive behavior.
3. Hypervigilance.
4. Exaggerated startle response.
5. Problems with concentration.
6. Sleep disturbance (e.g., difficulty falling or staying asleep or restless sleep).

criteria.label: F
criteria.text: Duration of the disturbance (Criteria B, C, D, and E) is more than 1 month.

criteria.label: G
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: H
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., medication, alcohol) or another medical condition.

Posttraumatic stress disorder.timeFrame: Duration of the disturbance is more than 1 month.
differentialDiagnosis: Other Specified Trauma- and Stressor-Related Disorder

Autism spectrum disorder.title: Autism Spectrum Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent deficits in social communication and social interaction across multiple contexts, as manifested by all of the following, currently or by history:
subcriteria: 1. Deficits in social-emotional reciprocity.
2. Deficits in nonverbal communicative behaviors used for social interaction.
3. Deficits in developing, maintaining, and understanding relationships.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Restricted, repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities, as manifested by at least two of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Stereotyped or repetitive motor movements, use of objects, or speech.
2. Insistence on sameness, inflexible adherence to routines, or ritualized patterns of verbal or nonverbal behavior.
3. Highly restricted, fixated interests that are abnormal in intensity or focus.
4. Hyper- or hyporeactivity to sensory input or unusual interest in sensory aspects of the environment.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period (but may not become fully manifest until social demands exceed limited capacities, or may be masked by learned strategies in later life).

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of current functioning.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder) or global developmental delay.

Autism spectrum disorder.timeFrame: Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period.
specifiers: with or without accompanying intellectual impairment
with or without accompanying language impairment
associated with a known medical or genetic condition or environmental factor
associated with another neurodevelopmental, mental, or behavioral disorder

Communication disorder.title: Communication Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent deficits in language, speech, or communication that are below those expected for age, resulting in functional limitations in effective communication, social participation, academic achievement, or occupational performance.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The deficits are not attributable to hearing or other sensory impairment, motor dysfunction, or another medical or neurological condition, and are not better explained by intellectual disability (intellectual developmental disorder) or global developmental delay.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to psychosis.

associatedFeatures: Difficulties may include problems with vocabulary, sentence structure, discourse, speech sound production, fluency, or social use of verbal and nonverbal communication.

Neurocognitive disorder.title: Neurocognitive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of significant cognitive decline from a previous level of performance in one or more cognitive domains (such as complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor, or social cognition) based on:
subcriteria: 1. Concern of the individual, a knowledgeable informant, or the clinician that there has been a significant decline in cognitive function; and
2. A substantial impairment in cognitive performance, preferably documented by standardized neuropsychological testing or, in its absence, another quantified clinical assessment.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits interfere with independence in everyday activities (i.e., at a minimum, requiring assistance with complex instrumental activities of daily living such as paying bills or managing medications).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits do not occur exclusively in the context of delirium.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder, schizophrenia).

associatedFeatures: May include psychotic symptoms such as delusions or hallucinations

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A problematic pattern of tobacco use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress, as manifested by at least two of the following, occurring within a 12-month period:
subcriteria: 1. Tobacco is often taken in larger amounts or over a longer period than was intended.
2. There is a persistent desire or unsuccessful efforts to cut down or control tobacco use.
3. A great deal of time is spent in activities necessary to obtain or use tobacco.
4. Craving, or a strong desire or urge to use tobacco.
5. Recurrent tobacco use resulting in a failure to fulfill major role obligations at work, school, or home.
6. Continued tobacco use despite having persistent or recurrent social or interpersonal problems caused or exacerbated by the effects of tobacco.
7. Important social, occupational, or recreational activities are given up or reduced because of tobacco use.
8. Recurrent tobacco use in situations in which it is physically hazardous.
9. Tobacco use is continued despite knowledge of having a persistent or recurrent physical or psychological problem that is likely to have been caused or exacerbated by tobacco.
10. Tolerance, as defined by either: (a) a need for markedly increased amounts of tobacco to achieve desired effect or (b) markedly diminished effect with continued use of the same amount of tobacco.

11. Withdrawal, as manifested by either: (a) the characteristic withdrawal syndrome for tobacco or (b) tobacco (or a closely related substance, such as nicotine) is taken to relieve or avoid withdrawal symptoms.

Metabolic syndrome.title: Metabolic Syndrome

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A diagnosis of metabolic syndrome requires the presence of at least three of the following conditions:
subcriteria: 1. Increased waist circumference (central obesity).
2. Elevated blood pressure.
3. Elevated fasting blood glucose.
4. Elevated triglycerides.
5. Reduced high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol.

associatedFeatures: Increased risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A period during which the full symptom criteria for a disorder are met.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A rating that indicates the current intensity of symptoms, often on a standardized scale, to help describe the seriousness of a disorder.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A distinct period during which the individual experiences symptoms that meet criteria for either a major depressive episode or a manic episode.

Active symptoms.title: Active Symptoms (Psychotic Disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following symptoms that are currently prominent:
subcriteria: 1. Hallucinations
2. Delusions
3. Disorganized speech

associatedFeatures: Symptoms are prominent and observable during the active phase of psychotic disorders.

Psychotic symptoms.title: Psychotic Symptoms

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of symptoms indicating a loss of contact with reality.
subcriteria: 1. Delusions (fixed, false beliefs not amenable to evidence to the contrary).
2. Hallucinations (perception-like experiences without external stimulus).
3. Disorganized thinking (typically inferred from disorganized speech).

associatedFeatures: May include grossly disorganized or abnormal motor behavior.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The ability to perform work or school-related tasks and responsibilities.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Impairment in the ability to interact effectively with others or maintain social relationships.

Prodromal stage.title: Prodromal Stage

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of subtle or subthreshold symptoms indicative of an early phase of a mental disorder (e.g., schizophrenia), which do not meet full diagnostic criteria for the disorder.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms represent a noticeable change from previous functioning.

Prodromal stage.timeFrame: Variable; typically precedes onset of full syndrome by weeks to months.
associatedFeatures: Mild disturbances in mood, cognition, or behavior
differentialDiagnosis: Other psychiatric disorders (e.g., depressive disorders, anxiety disorders)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A first-degree relative is defined as a family member who is a parent, sibling, or child of the individual.

Psychotic disorder due to another medica.title: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Prominent hallucinations or delusions are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance does not occur exclusively during the course of a delirium.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: The disturbance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

associatedFeatures: May include disorganized thinking or behavior
Insight into the psychotic symptoms is often limited

Mood-stabilizing medication.title: Mood-Stabilizing Medication

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Medications are used to treat mood disorders by stabilizing mood swings.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Commonly indicated for individuals with bipolar disorder or schizoaffective disorder.

associatedFeatures: May reduce frequency and severity of mood episodes
Can be used adjunctively with other psychotropic medications

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The proportion of individuals in a population who have ever experienced a particular disorder at any point in their lives.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The development of a reversible, substance-specific syndrome due to the recent ingestion of a substance.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Clinically significant problematic behavioral or psychological changes (e.g., impaired judgment, mood changes) that are attributable to the effect of the substance on the central nervous system and develop during or shortly after use of the substance.

Substance withdrawal.title: Substance Withdrawal

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Cessation of (or reduction in) substance use that has been heavy and prolonged.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The development of a substance-specific withdrawal syndrome due to cessation or reduction in use.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The withdrawal syndrome causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to another medical condition and are not better explained by another mental disorder.

Substance withdrawal.timeFrame: Symptoms typically develop within hours to a few days after cessation or reduction of substance use.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized thinking (speech)
4. Grossly disorganized or abnormal motor behavior
5. Negative symptoms (e.g., diminished emotional expression)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance results in significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Primary psychotic disorder.title: Primary Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following psychotic symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech
4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
5. Negative symptoms (e.g., diminished emotional expression or avolition)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse or medication) or another medical condition.

differentialDiagnosis: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The simultaneous presence of a substance use disorder (such as alcohol or drug dependence) alongside another mental disorder.

Assessment of cognition.title: Assessment of Cognition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Evaluation of mental processes, including memory, attention, and problem-solving abilities.

associatedFeatures: Important for distinguishing between different psychotic disorders.

Formication.title: Formication

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of tactile hallucinations involving the sensation of insects or bugs crawling on or under the skin.

associatedFeatures: May be associated with substance intoxication or withdrawal (e.g., cocaine, amphetamines, alcohol).
Can occur in the context of psychotic disorders or delirium.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more delusions in which the individual believes they are being harmed, harassed, or conspired against.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The delusion is not better explained by the effects of a substance, another medical condition, or another mental disorder (e.g., schizophrenia, mood disorder with psychotic features).

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual demonstrates the ability to distinguish between perceptions or beliefs that are based in reality and those that are not.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A recurrence of perceptual disturbances or hallucinations that were experienced during previous substance use.
subcriteria: 1. Occurs after the substance has been metabolized and eliminated.

Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disor.title: Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The re-experiencing, following cessation of use of a hallucinogen, of one or more of the perceptual symptoms that were experienced while intoxicated with the hallucinogen (e.g., geometric hallucinations, false perceptions of movement in the peripheral visual fields, flashes of color, intensified colors, trails of images of moving objects, positive afterimages, halos around objects, macropsia and micropsia).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The symptoms in Criterion A cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are not due to a general medical condition (e.g., anatomical lesions and infections of the brain, visual epilepsies) and are not better accounted for by another mental disorder (e.g., delirium, major neurocognitive disorder, schizophrenia) or hypnopompic hallucinations.

Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disor.timeFrame: Symptoms occur long after cessation of hallucinogen use.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of a significant decline from a previous level of performance in one or more cognitive domains (such as complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor, or social cognition) based on:
subcriteria: 1. Concern of the individual, a knowledgeable informant, or the clinician that there has been a significant decline in cognitive function; and
2. A substantial impairment in cognitive performance, preferably documented by standardized neuropsychological testing or, in its absence, another quantified clinical assessment.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits interfere with independence in everyday activities (i.e., at a minimum, requiring assistance with complex instrumental activities of daily living such as paying bills or managing medications).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits do not occur exclusively in the context of a delirium.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder, schizophrenia).

Primary Psychotic Disorder.title: Primary Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior, negative symptoms).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition.

differentialDiagnosis: Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The concurrent use of multiple medications by a patient.
subcriteria: 1. Medications may be prescribed for multiple medical conditions.
2. The combination of medications is not limited to a single therapeutic class.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The use of multiple medications increases the risk of adverse effects, including but not limited to psychosis.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A rating of the current severity of primary psychotic symptoms (delusions, hallucinations, abnormal psychomotor behavior, and negative symptoms) is required.
subcriteria: 1. Severity is rated on a 5-point scale from 0 (not present) to 4 (present and severe).

Abnormal Psychomotor Behavior.title: Abnormal Psychomotor Behavior

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of unusual movements or behaviors, which may include agitation, catatonia, or other motor disturbances associated with psychosis.

associatedFeatures: May present as motoric immobility, excessive motor activity, or peculiar voluntary movements.
comorbidity: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is a temporal relationship between the onset, exacerbation, or remission of a medical condition and the onset, exacerbation, or remission of a psychiatric disturbance.

Ictal Psychosis.title: Ictal Psychosis

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of psychotic symptoms (e.g., hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking) occurring during the ictal phase of a seizure in an individual with epilepsy.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The psychotic symptoms are temporally associated with the seizure activity and do not occur outside of the ictal phase.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., schizophrenia, brief psychotic disorder) or by the direct physiological effects of a substance.

Ictal Psychosis.timeFrame: During the ictal phase of a seizure
associatedFeatures: May include visual or auditory hallucinations, paranoia, or disorganized behavior concurrent with seizure activity

Postictal Psychosis.title: Postictal Psychosis

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking) occurring after a seizure in an individual with epilepsy.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Psychotic symptoms emerge during the postictal phase, typically within one week following a seizure, and are not present prior to the seizure.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another psychiatric disorder, substance/medication use, or another medical condition.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The psychotic episode causes clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Postictal Psychosis.timeFrame: Symptoms typically develop within one week after a seizure and last from several days up to a few weeks.
associatedFeatures: Confusion or disorientation during the postictal period

Interictal Psychosis.title: Interictal Psychosis

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of psychotic symptoms (e.g., delusions, hallucinations, disorganized thinking) occurring in an individual with a diagnosis of epilepsy.
subcriteria: 1. Psychotic symptoms are not attributable to an acute seizure (ictal or postictal phase).
2. Psychotic symptoms occur during the interictal phase (between seizures).

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The disturbance is not better explained by another psychotic disorder (e.g., schizophrenia, schizoaffective disorder) or by the direct physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The psychotic symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Interictal Psychosis.timeFrame: Psychotic symptoms persist for at least several days during the interictal phase.
associatedFeatures: Mood symptoms may be present but do not predominate.
May be associated with longstanding epilepsy, particularly temporal lobe epilepsy.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The observable characteristics or manifestations of a disorder.

Etiological Medical Condition.title: Etiological Medical Condition

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence from the history, physical examination, or laboratory findings that the disturbance is the direct pathophysiological consequence of another medical condition.

associatedFeatures: The underlying medical illness or disease causes or contributes to the development of a psychiatric disorder.

Mild Neurocognitive Disorder.title: Mild Neurocognitive Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: There is evidence of modest cognitive decline from a previous level of performance in one or more cognitive domains (complex attention, executive function, learning and memory, language, perceptual-motor, or social cognition) based on:
subcriteria: 1. Concern of the individual, a knowledgeable informant, or the clinician that there has been a mild decline in cognitive function; and
2. A modest impairment in cognitive performance, preferably documented by standardized neuropsychological testing or, in its absence, another quantified clinical assessment.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits do not interfere with capacity for independence in everyday activities (i.e., complex instrumental activities of daily living such as paying bills or managing medications are preserved, but greater effort, compensatory strategies, or accommodation may be required).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits do not occur exclusively in the context of delirium.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The cognitive deficits are not better explained by another mental disorder (e.g., major depressive disorder, schizophrenia).

associatedFeatures: Individuals may notice increased effort or compensatory strategies to maintain independence.
Mild changes in mood or personality may be present.

Auditory Hallucination.title: Auditory Hallucination

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of auditory perceptions, such as hearing sounds or voices, that are not actually present.
subcriteria: 1. The individual reports hearing voices or other sounds in the absence of external auditory stimuli.
2. The auditory experiences are perceived as real by the individual.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of various psychiatric or neurological disorders, including schizophrenia, mood disorders with psychotic features, or delirium.
comorbidity: Schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders

Visual Hallucination.title: Visual Hallucination

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of visual perception without external stimulus, involving seeing things that are not present.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of psychotic disorders, delirium, or substance intoxication.

Olfactory Hallucination.title: Olfactory Hallucination

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of olfactory hallucinations, defined as the perception of smelling odors that are not present.

associatedFeatures: May occur in the context of psychotic disorders, neurological conditions, or as an isolated symptom.

Catatonia Associated With Another Mental.title: Catatonia Associated With Another Mental Disorder (Catatonia Specifier)

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The clinical picture is dominated by three (or more) of the following symptoms:
subcriteria: 1. Stupor (i.e., no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment)
2. Catalepsy (i.e., passive induction of a posture held against gravity)
3. Waxy flexibility (i.e., slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner)
4. Mutism (i.e., no, or very little, verbal response [exclude if known aphasia])
5. Negativism (i.e., opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli)
6. Posturing (i.e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity)
7. Mannerism (i.e., odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions)
8. Stereotypy (i.e., repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements)
9. Agitation, not influenced by external stimuli
10. Grimacing
11. Echolalia (i.e., mimicking another's speech)
12. Echopraxia (i.e., mimicking another's movements)

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The catatonic symptoms occur in the context of another mental disorder (e.g., neurodevelopmental, psychotic, bipolar, or depressive disorder).

associatedFeatures: May be associated with increased risk of medical complications such as dehydration, malnutrition, or self-injury.
differentialDiagnosis: Catatonic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
comorbidity: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A condition involving the passive induction of a posture held against gravity.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: A state in which there is slight, even resistance to positioning by the examiner.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.

Mannerism.title: Mannerism

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.
Can include exaggerated or ritualistic movements that appear purposeful but are inappropriate or out of context.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Excessive motor activity that is not influenced by external stimuli.

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Distorted facial expressions, often repetitive or sustained.

Echolalia.title: Echolalia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual mimics or repeats another person's spoken words or phrases.

associatedFeatures: May be observed in neurodevelopmental disorders such as Autism Spectrum Disorder and in certain psychotic disorders.

Echopraxia.title: Echopraxia

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent or recurrent involuntary imitation of another person's movements.

associatedFeatures: Frequently observed in catatonia, schizophrenia spectrum disorders, and certain neurodevelopmental disorders.

Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome.title: Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Exposure to antipsychotic (neuroleptic) medication within the past 72 hours.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Development of severe muscle rigidity and elevated temperature associated with the use of antipsychotic medication.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Presence of at least two of the following:
subcriteria: 1. Diaphoresis
2. Dysphagia
3. Tremor
4. Incontinence
5. Changes in level of consciousness (e.g., stupor, delirium, coma)
6. Mutism or catatonic-like features
7. Tachycardia
8. Elevated or labile blood pressure
9. Leukocytosis
10. Laboratory evidence of muscle injury (e.g., elevated creatine phosphokinase)

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The symptoms are not better explained by another medical condition, substance intoxication or withdrawal, or another mental disorder.

associatedFeatures: Autonomic instability (e.g., fluctuating blood pressure, tachycardia)
Laboratory abnormalities (e.g., elevated creatine phosphokinase, leukocytosis)

Other Specified Schizophrenia Spectrum a.title: Other Specified Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Symptoms characteristic of schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders that cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The full criteria for any specific schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorder are not met.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The clinician chooses to communicate the specific reason that the presentation does not meet the criteria for any specific schizophrenia spectrum or other psychotic disorder (e.g., persistent auditory hallucinations in the absence of other symptoms).

specifiers: Specify reason (e.g., persistent auditory hallucinations, delusions with significant overlapping mood episodes, attenuated psychosis syndrome, delusional symptoms in partner of individual with delusional disorder)
associatedFeatures: May include symptoms such as hallucinations, delusions, disorganized thinking, or negative symptoms that do not fully meet criteria for a specific disorder
differentialDiagnosis: Unspecified Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorder

Persistent Auditory Hallucinations.title: Persistent Auditory Hallucinations

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Ongoing auditory hallucinations are present.
subcriteria: 1. Hallucinations consist exclusively of auditory phenomena (e.g., voices, sounds).
2. Hallucinations occur in clear consciousness.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: There are no other psychotic features (e.g., delusions, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior).

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

Persistent Auditory Hallucinations.timeFrame: Persistent (e.g., present for at least one month)
associatedFeatures: Mild anxiety or distress related to hallucinations

Delusions with Significant Overlapping M.title: Delusional Disorder with Significant Overlapping Mood Episodes

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Persistent delusions are present.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Mood episodes (major depressive or manic) have occurred and are present for a substantial portion of the total duration of the delusional disturbance.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: The criteria for delusional disorder are not met due to the significant overlap of mood episodes.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition and is not better explained by another mental disorder.

Delusions with Significant Overlapping M.timeFrame: Mood episodes are present for a substantial portion of the delusional disturbance.
associatedFeatures: Impairment in social or occupational functioning may occur.
differentialDiagnosis: Major Depressive Disorder with Psychotic Features

Attenuated Psychosis Syndrome.title: Attenuated Psychosis Syndrome

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: Presence of one or more of the following psychotic-like symptoms in attenuated form:
subcriteria: 1. Delusions
2. Hallucinations
3. Disorganized speech

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: Symptoms are less severe and more transient than those seen in full psychotic disorders.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Insight is relatively maintained; the individual recognizes the unusual nature of the experiences.

criteria.label: D
criteria.text: Symptoms have not reached the threshold for a full psychotic disorder.

criteria.label: E
criteria.text: Symptoms cause distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Attenuated Psychosis Syndrome.timeFrame: Symptoms are present at least once per week for the past month.
associatedFeatures: Increased risk for developing a psychotic disorder

Delusional Symptoms in Partner of Indivi.title: Delusional Symptoms in Partner of Individual with Delusional Disorder

criteria.label: A
criteria.text: The individual develops delusional beliefs that are similar in content to those of a person with an established delusional disorder with whom they have a close relationship.

criteria.label: B
criteria.text: The delusional beliefs are not better explained by another psychotic disorder (e.g., schizophrenia) or by the direct physiological effects of a substance or another medical condition.

criteria.label: C
criteria.text: Apart from the delusional beliefs, the individual's functioning is not markedly impaired and behavior is not obviously odd or bizarre.

associatedFeatures: The dominant partner is typically the primary source of the delusional content.
The secondary individual may not otherwise meet criteria for delusional disorder.
